{{Campaignbox Myanmar conflict}} The '''2016 Rohingya persecution in Myanmar''' occurred in late 2016 when [[Myanmar]]'s [[Tatmadaw|armed forces]] and [[Myanmar Police Force|police]] started a major crackdown on [[Rohingya people]] in [[Rakhine State]] in the country's northwestern region. The Burmese military have been accused of ethnic cleansing and genocide by various [[United Nations]] agencies, [[International Criminal Court]] officials, human rights groups, journalists, and governments including the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/myanmar-mass-graves-latest-rohingya-slaughter-genocide-ap/ |title=AP finds mass graves, latest evidence of Rohingya genocide in Myanmar |date=1 February 2018 |access-date=10 April 2018 |publisher=CBS News |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411174445/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/myanmar-mass-graves-latest-rohingya-slaughter-genocide-ap/# |archive-date=11 April 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-myanmar-rohingyas-20180313-story.html |title=U.N. genocide advisor: Myanmar waged 'scorched-earth campaign' against the Rohingya |date=13 March 2018 |access-date=10 April 2018 |publisher=Los Angeles Times |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411174500/http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-myanmar-rohingyas-20180313-story.html# |archive-date=11 April 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/12/asia/myanmar-rohingya-un-violence-genocide-intl/index.html |title=UN official convinced of Myanmar Rohingya 'genocide' |last=Wilkinson }}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |title=UN Security Council: End disgraceful inaction on Myanmar’s Rohingya crisis |date=11 December 2017 |publisher=Amnesty International }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/apr/10/rohingya-crisis-icc-prosecutor-seeks-power-to-investigate-crimes-against-humanity|title='Hallmarks of genocide': ICC web|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/03/1004232|title=‘No other conclusion,’ ethnic cleansing of Rohingyas in Myanmar continues – senior UN rights official|website=UN News|accessdate=10 April 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411111519/https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/03/1004232#|archive-date=11 April 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> has found evidence of wide-scale [[human rights]] violations, including [[extrajudicial killings]], [[gang rape]]s, [[arson]] and [[infanticide]]s, which the Burmese government dismisses as "exaggerations".<ref name="Jazeera2">{{cite news|title=Government dismisses claims of abuse against Rohingya|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/government-dismisses-claims-abuse-rohingya-170806095548889.html|accessdate=7 August 2017|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=6 August 2017|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170806211421/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/government-dismisses-claims-abuse-rohingya-170806095548889.html#|archive-date=6 August 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Reuters5">{{cite news|title=Myanmar rejects allegations of human rights abuses against Rohingya|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-rohingya-idUSKBN1AM0DU|accessdate=7 August 2017|work=[[Reuters]]|date=6 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170806183335/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-rohingya-idUSKBN1AM0DU#|archive-date=6 August 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The military crackdown on the Rohingya people has drawn criticism from the [[United Nations]] (which cited possible "crimes against humanity"), the human rights group [[Amnesty International]], the [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]], the government of neighboring [[Bangladesh]], and the government of [[Malaysia]] (where many Rohingya refugees have fled). The Myanmar leader and [[State Counsellor of Myanmar|State Counsellor]] [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] has particularly been criticized for her inaction and silence over the issue and for doing little to prevent military abuses. On 27 September 2018 members of the [[Canadian Parliament]] voted unanimously to dispossess Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi of her honorary Canadian citizenship for the atrocities against Rohingya Muslims.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/1379086/world# |title=Canada strips Aung San Suu Kyi of honorary citizenship |access-date=30 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181009030356/http://www.arabnews.com/node/1379086/world# |archive-date=9 October 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Background== {{Further|Persecution of Muslims in Myanmar|Religion in Myanmar|List of ethnic groups in Myanmar}}
The [[Rohingya people]] have been described as "amongst the world's least wanted"{{attribution needed|date=March 2018}}<ref>{{cite news |author=Mark Dummett |date=18 February 2010 |title=Bangladesh accused of 'crackdown' on Rohingya refugees |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8521280.stm |work=BBC News |accessdate=29 July 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121027120525/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8521280.stm# |archive-date=27 October 2012 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and "one of the world's most persecuted [[Minority group|minorities]]".{{attribution needed|date=March 2018}}<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.unhcr.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/refdaily?pass=52fc6fbd5&id=4fe952205| title=Myanmar, Bangladesh leaders 'to discuss Rohingya' |agency=Agence France-Presse | date=25 June 2012 | accessdate=29 July 2012}}</ref> The Rohingya are deprived of the right to free movement and of higher education.<ref>{{cite web|url =http://www.dandc.eu/en/article/myanmar-does-not-recognise-rohingya-citizens-ngo-expert-elaborates-our-interview|title ='The world's most persecuted people' Katja Dombrowski interviews Johannes Kaltenbach (Malteser International)|date =|website =|publisher =In: D+C, Vol.42.2015:5|accessdate =|archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20170902015910/https://www.dandc.eu/en/article/myanmar-does-not-recognise-rohingya-citizens-ngo-expert-elaborates-our-interview#|archive-date =2 September 2017|dead-url =no|df =dmy-all}}</ref> They have been denied Burmese citizenship since the [[Burmese nationality law]] was enacted.<ref name=rohingya>{{cite news |author=Jonathan Head |date=5 February 2009 |title=What drive the Rohingya to sea? |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7872635.stm |work=BBC News |accessdate=29 July 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120619004621/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7872635.stm# |archive-date=19 June 2012 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> They are not allowed to travel without official permission and were previously required to sign a commitment not to have more than two children, though the law was not strictly enforced. They are subjected to routine forced labor where typically a Rohingya man will have to give up one day a week to work on military or government projects and one night for sentry duty. The Rohingya have also lost a lot of arable land, which has been confiscated by the military to give to Buddhist settlers from elsewhere in Myanmar.{{Sfn|Crisis Group|2014|p=19}}<ref name=rohingya/>
[[Myanmar]], also known as ''Burma'', is a country in [[Southeast Asia]], bounded by the [[Bay of Bengal]], [[Bangladesh]] and [[India]] to the west, and [[China]], [[Laos]] and [[Thailand]] to the east. Democracy only [[2011–2015 Myanmar political reforms|recently emerged]] in Myanmar by arrangement with the military, who permitted a free election on 8 November 2015, which elevated [[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureate [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] to power after years of house arrest.<ref name="cia_factbook_burma">[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/resources/the-world-factbook/geos/bm.html "Burma"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170210022911/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/resources/the-world-factbook/geos/bm.html# |date=10 February 2017 }} section, [[Central Intelligence Agency]], U.S. Government, retrieved 13 February 2017.</ref>
Myanmar is predominantly Buddhist (88–90% of the population), with small minorities of other faiths, including a small minority of Muslims (4%).<ref name="situation_of_rohingya_2016_06_29_un_hchr">[[United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]], report: [https://documents-dds-ny.un.org/doc/UNDOC/GEN/G16/135/41/PDF/G1613541.pdf "Situation of human rights of Rohingya Muslims and other minorities in Myanmar''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214175752/https://documents-dds-ny.un.org/doc/UNDOC/GEN/G16/135/41/PDF/G1613541.pdf# |date=14 February 2017 }}, June 29, 2016, from ''Annual report of the [[United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] and reports of the Office of the High Commissioner and the [[Secretary-General]],'' Agenda item 2, Thirty-second session, [[Human Rights Council]], of the [[General Assembly]], of the [[United Nations]], retrieved 13 February 2017</ref><ref name="cia_factbook_burma" />
The western coastal province of [[Rakhine State]], is made up of the predominantly Buddhist [[Rakhine people|Rakhine]] (4%, about 2 million people) and the predominantly Muslim [[Rohingya]] (2%, about 1 million people). Tensions between Buddhist and Muslim communities have also led to violence in Rakhine State, with [[Nationalism|nationalist]] Buddhists often targeting Rohingyas.<ref name="ethnic-cleansing"/> The Rohingya are a distinct ethnicity with their own language and culture, but claim a long historical connection to Rakhine State.<ref name="situation_of_rohingya_2016_06_29_un_hchr" /><ref name="cia_factbook_burma" />
The Rohingya describe themselves as descendants of [[Arab people|Arab traders]] who settled in the region many generations ago.<ref name="BBC-Who"/> Scholars have stated that they have been present in the region since the 15th century.<ref name=Leider>{{cite book|url = https://www.academia.edu/7994939/_Rohingya_The_name_the_movement_the_quest_for_identity._ |title = Rohingya: the name, the movement and the quest for identity|last = Leider|first = Jacques|publisher = Myanmar Egress and the Myanmar Peace Center|year = 2013|isbn = |location = |pages = 204–255}}</ref> However, they have been denied citizenship by the government of Myanmar, which describes them as illegal immigrants from Bangladesh.<ref name="BBC-Who"/>
In modern times, [[persecution]] of Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar dates back to the 1970s.<ref name=VOA>{{cite news |title=Rohingya Refugees Seek to Return Home to Myanmar |url=http://www.voanews.com/a/rohingya-refugees-seek-to-return-home-to-myanmar/3617130.html |accessdate=9 December 2016 |newspaper=Voice of America |date=30 November 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202121902/http://www.voanews.com/a/rohingya-refugees-seek-to-return-home-to-myanmar/3617130.html# |archive-date=2 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Since then, Rohingya people have regularly been made the target of persecution by the government and [[Nationalism|nationalist]] [[Buddhism|Buddhists]].<ref name= ethnic-cleansing/> The tension between the various religious groups in the country was often exploited by the past military rulers of Myanmar.<ref name="BBC-Who"/> According to [[Amnesty International]], the Rohingya have suffered from human rights violations under past [[military dictatorship]]s since 1978, and many have fled to neighboring Bangladesh as a result.<ref name="Amn">{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/ASA16/005/2004/ |title=Myanmar – The Rohingya Minority: Fundamental Rights Denied |date=2004 |author=Amnesty International |accessdate=11 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141213205322/http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/ASA16/005/2004 |archivedate=13 December 2014 }}</ref> In 2005, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees had assisted with the repatriation of Rohingyas from Bangladesh, but allegations of human rights abuses in the refugee camps threatened this effort.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newagebd.com/2005/may/21/front.html#9 |title=UNHCR threatens to wind up Bangladesh operations |publisher=New Age BDNEWS, Dhaka |date=21 May 2005 |accessdate=25 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090425140346/http://www.newagebd.com/2005/may/21/front.html |archivedate=25 April 2009 }}</ref> In 2015, 140,000 Rohingyas remain in IDP camps after communal riots in 2012.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-23077537|title = The unending plight of Burma's unwanted Rohingyas|last = Head|first = Jonathan|date = 1 July 2013|work = |access-date = 11 February 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150328085757/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-23077537#|archive-date = 28 March 2015|dead-url = no|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
Before the most recent violence, in its 17 March 2016 ''Atrocities Prevention Report'',<ref name="atrocities_report_2016_03_17_us_state_dept">[https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/254807.htm ''Atrocities Prevention Report,''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214002422/https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/254807.htm# |date=14 February 2017 }} 17 March 2016, [[Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor]], Office of the [[Under Secretary for Civilian Security, Democracy, and Human Rights]], United States [[State Department|Department of State]], retrieved 12 February 2017 (NOTE: This document alternates, repeatedly, between sections on the Middle East, and sections on "Burma.")</ref> the [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]] summarized:
{{quote| The situation in Rakhine State is grim, in part due to a mix of long-term historical tensions between the Rakhine and Rohingya communities, socio-political conflict, socio-economic underdevelopment, and a long-standing marginalization of both Rakhine and Rohingya by the Government of Burma. The World Bank estimates Rakhine State has the highest poverty rate in Burma (78 percent) and is the poorest state in the country. The lack of investment by the central government has resulted in poor infrastructure and inferior social services, while lack of rule of law has led to inadequate security conditions.<ref name="atrocities_report_2016_03_17_us_state_dept" />
Members of the Rohingya community in particular reportedly face abuses by the Government of Burma, including those involving torture, unlawful arrest and detention, restricted movement, restrictions on religious practice, and discrimination in employment and access to social services. In 2012, intercommunal conflict led to the death of nearly 200 Rohingya and the displacement of 140,000 people. Throughout 2013–2015 isolated incidents of violence against Rohingya individuals continued to take place.<ref name="atrocities_report_2016_03_17_us_state_dept" /> }}
==Initial border incidents== {{main|2016–17 Northern Rakhine State clashes}} According to Myanmar state reports, on 9 October 2016, armed individuals attacked several border police posts in [[Rakhine State]], leaving nine police personnel dead.<ref>{{cite news|title=Myanmar says nine police killed by insurgents on Bangladesh border|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/10/myanmar-nine-police-killed-insurgents-bangladesh-border|newspaper=The Guardian|date=10 October 2016|access-date=11 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161210021228/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/10/myanmar-nine-police-killed-insurgents-bangladesh-border#|archive-date=10 December 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Weapons and ammunitions were also looted. The attack took place mainly in [[Maungdaw Township]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Rakhine border raids kill nine police officers|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/national-news/22992-rakhine-border-raids-kill-nine-police-officers.html|publisher=Myanmar Times|date=10 October 2016|accessdate=10 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118050130/http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/national-news/22992-rakhine-border-raids-kill-nine-police-officers.html#|archive-date=18 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A newly formed insurgent group, [[Harakah al-Yaqin]], claimed responsibility a week later.<ref name="BKP1">{{cite news|title=Islamist fears rise in Rohingya-linked violence|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asia/1111481/islamist-fears-rise-in-rohingya-linked-violence|accessdate=5 November 2016|work=Bangkok Post|publisher=Post Publishing PCL}}</ref>
==Crackdown== Following the police camp incidents, the Myanmar military began a major crackdown in the villages of northern Rakhine state. In the initial operation, dozens of people were killed and many were arrested.<ref name="Lady-CNN">{{cite web |url= http://edition.cnn.com/2016/11/17/asia/myanmar-rohingya-aung-san-suu-kyi/ |title= Is The Lady listening? Aung San Suu Kyi accused of ignoring Myanmar's Muslims |author= James Griffiths |date= 25 November 2016 |publisher= CNN |access-date= 11 December 2016 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20161220145049/http://edition.cnn.com/2016/11/17/asia/myanmar-rohingya-aung-san-suu-kyi/# |archive-date= 20 December 2016 |dead-url= no |df= dmy-all }}</ref> As the crackdown continued, the casualties increased. Arbitrary arrest, [[extrajudicial killing]]s, gang rapes, brutalities against civilians, and [[looting]] were carried out.<ref name=Amnesty-Vicious>{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/press-releases/2016/12/myanmar-security-forces-target-rohingya-viscious-scorched-earth-campaign/ |title=Myanmar: Security Forces Target Rohingya During Vicious Rakhine Scorched-Earth Campaign |author= |date=19 December 2016 |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |access-date=20 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202001842/https://www.amnesty.org/en/press-releases/2016/12/myanmar-security-forces-target-rohingya-viscious-scorched-earth-campaign/# |archive-date=2 February 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="Shoot-first">{{cite web |url= http://edition.cnn.com/2016/11/15/asia/myanmar-rakhine-state-unrest/ |title= 'Shoot first, ask questions later': Violence intensifies in Rakhine State |author= Joshua Berlinger |date= 16 November 2016 |publisher= CNN |access-date= 11 December 2016 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20161220145001/http://edition.cnn.com/2016/11/15/asia/myanmar-rakhine-state-unrest/# |archive-date= 20 December 2016 |dead-url= no |df= dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="TI-UN-Kyi"/> According to media reports, hundreds of Rohingya people had been killed by December 2016, and many had fled Myanmar as refugees to take shelter in the nearby areas of [[Bangladesh]].<ref name="21000-rohingya">{{cite news|title=21,000 Rohingya Muslims flee to Bangladesh to escape persecution in Myanmar|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/21000-rohingya-muslims-flee-bangladesh-escape-persecution-myanmar-1595115|newspaper=International Business Times|date=6 December 2016|access-date=11 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161207154028/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/21000-rohingya-muslims-flee-bangladesh-escape-persecution-myanmar-1595115#|archive-date=7 December 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name= ethnic-cleansing/><ref name=Aljazeera-humanity/><ref name="IBT-1250"/><ref name="Lady-CNN"/>
In late November, [[Human Rights Watch]] released [[satellite image]]s which showed that about 1,250 Rohingya houses in five villages had been burned down by the security forces.<ref name="IBT-1250">{{cite news|title=New wave of destruction sees 1,250 houses destroyed in Myanmar's Rohingya villages|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/new-wave-destruction-sees-1250-houses-destroyed-myanmars-rohingya-villages-1592582|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=21 November 2016|access-date=11 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220101309/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/new-wave-destruction-sees-1250-houses-destroyed-myanmars-rohingya-villages-1592582#|archive-date=20 December 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Shoot-first"/> The media and the human rights groups frequently reported intense human rights violations by the Myanmar military.<ref name="Lady-CNN"/><ref name="Shoot-first"/> During one incident in November, the Myanmar military used [[Attack helicopter|helicopter gunships]] to shoot and kill the villagers.<ref name= ethnic-cleansing/><ref name=Amnesty-Vicious/><ref name=Aljazeera-humanity/> As of November 2016, Myanmar had yet to allow the media and human rights groups to enter the persecuted areas.<ref name= ethnic-cleansing/> Consequently, the exact figures of civilian casualties remained unknown. The Rakhine State was termed an "information black hole".<ref name="Shoot-first"/>
Those who fled Myanmar to escape persecution reported that women had been gang raped, men killed, houses torched, and young children thrown into burning houses.<ref name="raped-one">{{cite news |title= 'They raped us one by one', says Rohingya woman who fled Myanmar |url= https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/167613-They-raped-us-one-by-one-says-Rohingya-woman-who-fled-Myanmar |accessdate= 9 December 2016 |newspaper= The News International |date= 25 November 2016 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20161210071207/https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/167613-They-raped-us-one-by-one-says-Rohingya-woman-who-fled-Myanmar# |archive-date= 10 December 2016 |dead-url= no |df= dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=UN-to-Suu-Kyi>{{cite news |title= UN calls on Suu Kyi to visit crisis-hit Rakhine |url= http://www.thedailystar.net/world/south-asia/un-calls-suu-kyi-visit-crisis-hit-rakhine-1327606 |accessdate= 10 December 2016 |newspaper= The Daily Star |date= 9 December 2016 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20161210142803/http://www.thedailystar.net/world/south-asia/un-calls-suu-kyi-visit-crisis-hit-rakhine-1327606# |archive-date= 10 December 2016 |dead-url= no |df= dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=NYT-Callous/> The boats carrying Rohingya refugees on [[Naf River]] were often gunned down by the Myanmar military.<ref name=Gulf-Times>{{cite news |title=Hundreds of Rohingya flee Yangon crackdown |url=http://www.gulf-times.com/story/521473/Hundreds-of-Rohingya-flee-Yangon-crackdown |newspaper=Gulf Times |date=17 November 2016 |access-date=11 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161209030256/http://www.gulf-times.com/story/521473/Hundreds-of-Rohingya-flee-Yangon-crackdown# |archive-date=9 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 3 February 2017, the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] (OHCHR) released a report based on interviews with more than 200 Rohingya refugees, which said that the abuses included [[gang-rape]], mass killing, and killing children.<ref name="BBC 2017">{{cite news|title=UN condemns 'devastating' Rohingya abuse in Myanmar|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-38858655|accessdate=4 February 2017|publisher=BBC News|date=3 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170203172900/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-38858655#|archive-date=3 February 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Al Jazeera 2017">{{cite news|title='Hundreds of Rohingyas' killed in Myanmar crackdown|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/02/rohingyas-killed-myanmar-crackdown-170203101817841.html|accessdate=4 February 2017|work=Al Jazeera|date=3 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170204005542/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/02/rohingyas-killed-myanmar-crackdown-170203101817841.html#|archive-date=4 February 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Hindu 2017">{{cite news|title=Myanmar Army committed crimes against humanity: UN|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/Myanmar-Army-committed-crimes-against-humanity-UN/article17191102.ece|accessdate=4 February 2017|work=The Hindu|date=4 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170302124832/http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/Myanmar-Army-committed-crimes-against-humanity-UN/article17191102.ece#|archive-date=2 March 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Nearly half of the interviewees stated that family members of theirs had been killed.<ref name="BBC 2017" /> Half of the women interviewed stated that they had been raped or sexually assaulted: the report described the sexual violence as "massive and systematic".<ref name="Al Jazeera 2017"/> The army and police were stated to have burned "homes, schools, markets, shops, and mosques" belonging to or used by the Rohingya people.<ref name="BBC 2017" /><ref name="OHCHR1">[http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=21142&LangID=E "Devastating cruelty against Rohingya children, women and men detailed in UN human rights report,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170213090505/http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=21142&LangID=E# |date=13 February 2017 }} 3 February 2017, Office of the [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]] (OHCHR), [[United Nations]], retrieved 12 February 2017</ref><ref name="OHCHR2">[http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Countries/MM/FlashReport3Feb2017.pdf "FLASH REPORT: Report of OHCHR mission to Bangladesh: Interviews with Rohingyas fleeing from Myanmar since 9 October 2016,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214225925/http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Countries/MM/FlashReport3Feb2017.pdf# |date=14 February 2017 }} 3 February 2017, Office of the [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]] (OHCHR), [[United Nations]], retrieved 12 February 2017</ref>
In March 2017, a police document obtained by [[Reuters]] listed 423 Rohingyas detained by the police since 9 October 2016, 13 of whom were children, the youngest being ten years old. Two police captains in Maungdaw verified the document and justified the arrests, with one of them saying, "We the police have to arrest those who collaborated with the attackers, children or not, but the court will decide if they are guilty; we are not the ones who decide." Myanmar police also claimed that the children had confessed to their alleged crimes during interrogations, and that they were not beaten or pressured during questioning. The average age of those detained is 34, the youngest is 10, and the oldest is 75.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lone|first1=Wa|last2=Lewis|first2=Simon|last3=Das|first3=Krishna N.|title=Exclusive: Children among hundreds of Rohingya detained in Myanmar crackdown|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-rohingya-detainees-exclusive-idUSKBN16N342|accessdate=18 March 2017|work=[[Reuters]]|date=17 March 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170317192643/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-rohingya-detainees-exclusive-idUSKBN16N342#|archive-date=17 March 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Hundreds of Rohingya held for consorting with insurgents in Bangladesh - Regional {{!}} The Star Online|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/regional/2017/03/18/children-among-detainees-hundreds-of-rohingya-held-for-consorting-with-insurgents-in-bangladesh/|accessdate=18 March 2017|work=www.thestar.com.my|date=18 March 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318020115/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/regional/2017/03/18/children-among-detainees-hundreds-of-rohingya-held-for-consorting-with-insurgents-in-bangladesh/#|archive-date=18 March 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 24 October 2018, [[Marzuki Darusman]] chairman of the Independent International Fact-Finding Mission on Myanmar reported some examples of atrocities committed by Myanmar Security forces against Rohingya Muslims.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.un.org/press/en/2018/sc13552.doc.htm# |title=Head of Human Rights Fact‑Finding Mission on Myanmar Urges Security Council to Ensure Accountability for Serious Violations against Rohingya |access-date=27 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181028033707/https://www.un.org/press/en/2018/sc13552.doc.htm# |archive-date=28 October 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> This Independent International Fact-Finding Mission was established in 2017, by the UN [[Human Rights Council]] in Geneva.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ohchr.org/EN/HRBodies/HRC/MyanmarFFM/Pages/ReportoftheMyanmarFFM.aspx# |title=Report of Independent International Fact-Finding Mission on Myanmar |access-date=27 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181019232309/https://www.ohchr.org/EN/HRBodies/HRC/MyanmarFFM/Pages/ReportoftheMyanmarFFM.aspx# |archive-date=19 October 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Refugee crisis== [[File:Kutupalong Refugee Camp (John Owens-VOA).jpg|thumb|[[Kutupalong refugee camp]] in Bangladesh in March 2017]]
An estimated 92,000 Rohingya people had been displaced because of the violence by January 2017;<ref name="reliefweb">{{cite news|title=Myanmar: Humanitarian Bulletin, Issue 4 {{!}} October 2016 - January 2017|url=http://reliefweb.int/report/myanmar/myanmar-humanitarian-bulletin-issue-4-october-2016-january-2017|accessdate=30 January 2017|work=ReliefWeb|date=30 January 2017|language=English|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170130101239/http://reliefweb.int/report/myanmar/myanmar-humanitarian-bulletin-issue-4-october-2016-january-2017#|archive-date=30 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> around 65,000 had fled from Myanmar into neighboring [[Bangladesh]] between October 2016 and January 2017,<ref name="bangladeshbbc">{{cite news|title=Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh face relocation to island|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-38799586|accessdate=1 February 2017|work=BBC News|date=30 January 2017|publisher=BBC News|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201000733/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-38799586#|archive-date=1 February 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="bangladeshabc">{{cite news|title=Bangladesh Rohingya relocation plan to prevent 'intermingling'|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-02-01/bangladesh-to-relocate-rohingya-refugees/8228196|accessdate=1 February 2017|work=ABC News|agency=Reuters|date=1 February 2017|language=en-AU|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131152824/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-02-01/bangladesh-to-relocate-rohingya-refugees/8228196#|archive-date=31 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> while 23,000 others had been [[Internally displaced persons|internally displaced]].<ref name="reliefweb" />
In February 2017, the [[government of Bangladesh]] announced that it planned to relocate the new refugees and another 232,000 Rohingya refugees already in the country to [[Thengar Char]], a sedimentary island in the [[Bay of Bengal]].<ref name="bangladeshbbc" /><ref name="bangladeshaj">{{cite news|title=Bangladesh pushes on with Rohingya island plan|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/01/bangladesh-pushes-rohingya-island-plan-170131050223171.html|accessdate=1 February 2017|work=www.aljazeera.com|agency=AFP|publisher=Al Jazeera|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201005752/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/01/bangladesh-pushes-rohingya-island-plan-170131050223171.html#|archive-date=1 February 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The island first appeared around 2007, formed from washed down [[silt]] from the [[Meghna River]].<ref name="bangladeshbbc" /><ref name="bangladeshaj" /> The nearest inhabited land, [[Hatiya island]] is around 30 km away.<ref name="bangladeshbbc"/> News agencies quoted a regional official describing the plan as "terrible".<ref name="bangladeshaj"/> The move has received substantial opposition from a number of quarters. Human rights groups have described the plan as a forced relocation.<ref name="bangladeshaj"/><ref name="bangladeshbbc" /> Additionally, concerns have been raised about the living conditions on the island, which is low-lying and prone to flooding.<ref name="bangladeshaj"/><ref name="bangladeshbbc" /> The island has been described as "only accessible during winter and a haven for pirates".<ref name="bangladeshaj"/><ref name="BBC 2017"/> It is nine hours away from the camps in which the Rohingya refugees currently live.<ref name="bangladeshaj"/><ref name="bangladeshbbc" />
On 30 April 2017 [[Sri Lanka]] intercepted and detained an India-origin boat of 32 Rohingya refugees off its northern coast after it entered Sri Lankan waters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/05/sri-lanka-navy-detains-suspected-rohingya-refugees-170501064928243.html|title=Sri Lanka navy detains suspected Rohingya refugees|website=www.aljazeera.com|accessdate=14 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814003527/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/05/sri-lanka-navy-detains-suspected-rohingya-refugees-170501064928243.html#|archive-date=14 August 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-4460392/Sri-Lanka-rescues-30-Rohingya-aboard-Indian-boat.html|title=15-day-old baby among the 30 Rohingya refugees rescued by Sri Lanka|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170511072536/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-4460392/Sri-Lanka-rescues-30-Rohingya-aboard-Indian-boat.html#|archive-date=11 May 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In May 2017, [[Bangladesh]] detained 12 Rohingya people and 2 people smugglers who attempted to leave the country by boat for [[Malaysia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/2017/05/10/bangladesh-detains-rohingya-attempting-boat-trip-malaysia|title=Bangladesh detains Rohingya attempting boat trip to Malaysia|website=www.thesundaily.my|accessdate=14 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814140524/http://www.thesundaily.my/news/2017/05/10/bangladesh-detains-rohingya-attempting-boat-trip-malaysia#|archive-date=14 August 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 14 August 2017 [[India]] announced that it was to deport an estimated 40,000 Rohingya refugees including 14,000 of those registered with the U.N. refugee agency as well. In the months leading up to the announcement, a string of anti-Rohingya protests had been held in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-rohingya-india-idUSKCN1AU0UC|title=India says to deport all Rohingya regardless of U.N. registration|date=14 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=14 August 2017|via=Reuters|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814154221/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-rohingya-india-idUSKCN1AU0UC#|archive-date=14 August 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Related incidents== In January 2017, at least four police officers were detained by government authorities after a video emerged online of security forces beating Rohingya Muslims in November 2016. In the video, Rohingya men and boys were forced to sit in rows with their hands behind their head, while they were beaten with batons and kicked. This was the first incident in which the government punished its own security forces in the region since the beginning of the crackdown.<ref>{{cite news|title=Burma detains police officers caught on video beating Rohingya Muslims|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/burma-rohingya-muslims-beating-abuse-video-aung-san-suu-kyi-a7505816.html|accessdate=3 January 2017|work=The Independent|date=2 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170103012141/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/burma-rohingya-muslims-beating-abuse-video-aung-san-suu-kyi-a7505816.html#|archive-date=3 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Myanmar to take action after Rakhine assault video goes viral|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-01-03/myanmar-government-admits-video-shows-police-beating-villagers/8158050|accessdate=3 January 2017|work=ABC News|date=3 January 2017|language=en-AU|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170103001951/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-01-03/myanmar-government-admits-video-shows-police-beating-villagers/8158050#|archive-date=3 January 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 21 January 2017, the bodies of three Rohingya men were found in shallow graves in [[Maungdaw]]. The men were locals who had worked closely with the local administration, and the government believes they were murdered by Rohingya insurgents in a reprisal attack.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gerin|first1=Roseanne|last2=Myaung Nyane|first2=Khin|title=Three More Muslim Men Found Dead in Myanmar's Maungdaw|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/myanmar/three-more-muslim-men-found-dead-in-myanmars-maungdaw-01232017154609.html|accessdate=24 January 2017|work=Radio Free Asia|date=21 January 2017|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202041107/http://www.rfa.org/english/news/myanmar/three-more-muslim-men-found-dead-in-myanmars-maungdaw-01232017154609.html#|archive-date=2 February 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 4 July 2017, a mob of at least a hundred [[Rakhine people|Rakhine]] [[Buddhism|Buddhists]] in [[Sittwe]] attacked seven Rohingya men from Dapaing camp for [[internally displaced persons]] with bricks,<ref name="Independent">{{cite news|title=Mob kills Muslim man with bricks in street attack as police flee scene|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/burma-rohingya-muslims-mob-kills-maung-nu-rakhine-buddhists-sittwe-aung-san-suu-kyi-a7824091.html|accessdate=9 July 2017|work=The Independent|date=5 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170708133808/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/burma-rohingya-muslims-mob-kills-maung-nu-rakhine-buddhists-sittwe-aung-san-suu-kyi-a7824091.html#|archive-date=8 July 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> killing one and severely injuring another. The Rohingya men were being escorted by police to Sittwe's docks to purchase boats, but were attacked despite armed guards being present nearby.<ref>{{cite news|title=BREAKING: Mob Kill Rohingya Muslim in Rakhine|url=https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/breaking-mob-kill-rohingya-muslim-rakhine.html|accessdate=4 July 2017|work=The Irrawaddy|date=4 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170704172157/https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/breaking-mob-kill-rohingya-muslim-rakhine.html#|archive-date=4 July 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=One Rohingya man killed, six hurt after argument in Myanmar's Sittwe|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-rohingya-idUSKBN19P1O8|accessdate=4 July 2017|work=Reuters|date=2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170708211819/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-myanmar-rohingya-idUSKBN19P1O8#|archive-date=8 July 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Mob in western Myanmar kills Rohingya despite police guards|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/news/world/mob-western-myanmar-kills-rohingya-police-guards-article-1.3300045|accessdate=4 July 2017|work=NY Daily News|language=en}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> According to a spokesman for the [[Ministry of Home Affairs (Myanmar)|Burmese Ministry of Home Affairs]], an unarmed junior policeman was with the Rohingya men at the time of the attack, but was unable to stop the attackers.<ref name="Independent" /> One man was arrested in relation to the attacks on 26 July 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=Myanmar Police Arrest Man For Deadly Rakhine Mob Attack on Rohingya|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/myanmar/myanmar-police-arrest-man-for-deadly-rakhine-mob-attack-on-rohingya-07262017144831.html|accessdate=26 July 2017|work=Radio Free Asia|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170903073324/http://www.rfa.org/english/news/myanmar/myanmar-police-arrest-man-for-deadly-rakhine-mob-attack-on-rohingya-07262017144831.html#|archive-date=3 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 30 July 2017, packages of [[high energy biscuits]] aided from the United Nations [[World Food Program]] (WFP) were discovered in a terrorist hideout in the Mayu mountain range in [[Maungdaw Township]]. The [[Rakhine State Government]] and WFP investigated the discovery of the biscuits for whether it represented a misuse of food assistance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://coconuts.co/yangon/news/suu-kyis-office-links-un-aid-violent-attackers/|title=Suu Kyi’s office links UN aid to 'violent attackers' – Coconuts Yangon|date=1 August 2017|publisher=|access-date=22 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119013602/https://coconuts.co/yangon/news/suu-kyis-office-links-un-aid-violent-attackers/#|archive-date=19 November 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 31 July 2017, three decapitated bodies were found in [[Rathedaung Township]]. According to a government official, they were murdered by Rohingya insurgents.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/burma/bodies-found-arrests-made-tense-northern-rakhine.html|title=Bodies Found, Arrests Made in Tense Northern Rakhine|date=1 August 2017|publisher=|access-date=22 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180122102052/https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/burma/bodies-found-arrests-made-tense-northern-rakhine.html#|archive-date=22 January 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 3 August 2017, bodies of six ethnic [[Mro people|Mro]] farmers, reportedly killed by Muslim militants were found in Maungdaw Township.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/burma/six-bodies-gunshot-machete-wounds-found-maungdaw.html|title=Six Bodies With Gunshot, Machete Wounds Found in Maungdaw|date=3 August 2017|publisher=|access-date=22 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180122101120/https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/burma/six-bodies-gunshot-machete-wounds-found-maungdaw.html#|archive-date=22 January 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dvb.no/news/two-shot-dead-four-missing-northern-arakan/76717|title=Two shot dead, four missing in northern Arakan- DVB Multimedia Group|date=3 August 2017|publisher=|access-date=22 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929160742/http://www.dvb.no/news/two-shot-dead-four-missing-northern-arakan/76717#|archive-date=29 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Criticism== The military crackdown on Rohingya people drew criticism from various quarters. Human rights group [[Amnesty International]] and organizations such as the [[United Nations]] have labeled the military crackdown on the Rohingya minority as [[crimes against humanity]] and have said that the military had made the civilians a target of "a systematic campaign of violence".<ref name=Aljazeera-humanity>{{cite news |title=Rohingya abuse may be crimes against humanity: Amnesty |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/12/rohingya-crimes-humanity-amnesty-161219045655733.html |newspaper=Al Jazeera |date=19 December 2016 |access-date=5 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170105160359/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/12/rohingya-crimes-humanity-amnesty-161219045655733.html# |archive-date=5 January 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Myanmar's Rohingya campaign 'may be crime against humanity' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/19/myanmars-rohingya-campaign-may-be-against-humanity |newspaper=The Guardian |date=19 December 2016 |author=Oliver Holmes |access-date=5 January 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170106013700/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/19/myanmars-rohingya-campaign-may-be-against-humanity# |archive-date=6 January 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-38362275 |title=Amnesty accuses Myanmar military of 'crimes against humanity' |author= |date=19 December 2016 |work=[[BBC]] |access-date=21 July 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171007185015/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-38362275# |archive-date=7 October 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="BBC-Who">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-38168917 |title=Who will help Myanmar's Rohingya? |author=Kevin Ponniah |date=5 December 2016 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |access-date=21 July 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180724231413/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-38168917# |archive-date=24 July 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Aung San Suu Kyi]] has been criticized in particular for her silence and lack of action over the issue, as well as for failing to prevent human rights abuses by the military.<ref name="Lady-CNN"/><ref name= ethnic-cleansing/><ref name= "BBC-Who"/> She stated in response: "show me a country without human rights issues."<ref name="TI-UN-Kyi">{{cite news |title=UN calls on Burma's Aung San Suu Kyi to halt 'ethnic cleansing' of Rohingya Muslims |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/burma-rohingya-myanmar-muslims-united-nations-calls-on-suu-kyi-a7465036.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=10 December 2016 |author=Matt Broomfield |accessdate=12 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161211125521/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/burma-rohingya-myanmar-muslims-united-nations-calls-on-suu-kyi-a7465036.html# |archive-date=11 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The former head of the United Nations, [[Kofi Annan]], after a week-long visit in the Rakhine state, expressed deep concern about reports of human rights violations in the area.<ref name="NYT-Kofi-Annan">{{cite news |title=Kofi Annan, in Myanmar, Voices Concern Over Reported Abuses of Rohingya |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/06/world/asia/kofi-annan-myanmar-rohingya.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=6 December 2016 |access-date=1 March 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170120053746/https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/06/world/asia/kofi-annan-myanmar-rohingya.html# |archive-date=20 January 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He was leading a nine-member commission which was formed in August 2016 to look into and make recommendations on improving the situation in the state.<ref name="NYT-Kofi-Annan"/><ref name= "BBC-Who"/>
The [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]] has also expressed concern about the violence in Rakhine State and the displacement of Rohingyas.<ref name= ethnic-cleansing/> The government of [[Malaysia]] has condemned the crackdown in Rakhine State, with [[Malaysia–Myanmar relations#Malaysia protest to Myanmar|ongoing protests]] in the country. In a protest rally in early December, [[Malaysia]]'s prime minister [[Najib Razak]] criticized the Myanmar authority for military crackdown on Rohingya Muslims, and described the ongoing persecution as "genocide".<ref>{{cite news |title='Enough is enough': Malaysian PM Najib Razak asks Aung San Suu Kyi to prevent Rohingya violence |url=http://www.firstpost.com/world/enough-is-enough-malaysian-pm-najib-razak-asks-aung-san-suu-kyi-to-prevent-rohingya-violence-3138748.html |newspaper=[[Firstpost]] |date=4 December 2016 |author=Associated Press |accessdate=12 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161206145425/http://www.firstpost.com/world/enough-is-enough-malaysian-pm-najib-razak-asks-aung-san-suu-kyi-to-prevent-rohingya-violence-3138748.html# |archive-date=6 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Malaysia PM urges world to act against 'genocide' of Myanmar's Rohingya |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/04/malaysia-pm-urges-world-to-act-against-genocide-of-myanmars-rohingya |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=4 December 2016 |author=Associated Press |accessdate=12 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161210021226/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/04/malaysia-pm-urges-world-to-act-against-genocide-of-myanmars-rohingya# |archive-date=10 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Earlier, terming the violence against Rohingya Muslim minority as "ethnic cleansing", Malaysia stated the situation was of international concern.<ref name="TI-ethnic">{{cite news |title=Malaysia condemns violence against Rohingya Muslims in Burma as 'ethnic cleansing' |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/malaysia-violence-rohingya-muslims-burma-myanmar-ethnic-cleansing-a7453586.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=3 December 2016 |author=Harriet Agerholm |accessdate=12 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161205132050/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/malaysia-violence-rohingya-muslims-burma-myanmar-ethnic-cleansing-a7453586.html# |archive-date=5 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Malaysia also cancelled two [[football]] matches with Myanmar in protest of the crackdown.<ref>{{cite news |title=Football: Malaysia cancels two matches with Myanmar over Rohingya crackdown |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/sports/football/malaysia-cancels-two-matches-myanmar-over-rohingya-crackdown-1323466 |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=1 December 2016 |access-date=12 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220102003/http://www.thedailystar.net/sports/football/malaysia-cancels-two-matches-myanmar-over-rohingya-crackdown-1323466# |archive-date=20 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="21000-rohingya"/>
In November 2016, a senior United Nations official, John McKissick, accused Myanmar of conducting [[ethnic cleansing]] in the Rakhine state to free it from the Muslim minority.<ref name=ethnic-cleansing>{{cite news|title=Myanmar seeking ethnic cleansing, says UN official as Rohingya flee persecution|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/nov/24/rohingya-flee-to-bangladesh-to-escape-myanmar-military-strikes|newspaper=The Guardian|date=24 November 2016|access-date=11 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161210021346/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/nov/24/rohingya-flee-to-bangladesh-to-escape-myanmar-military-strikes#|archive-date=10 December 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="TI-ethnic"/> McKissick is the head of a UN refugee agency based in the Bangladeshi town [[Cox's Bazar]]. Later that month, [[Bangladesh]] summoned the Myanmar envoy in its country to express "tremendous concern" over the Rohingya persecution.<ref>{{cite news |title=B'desh asks Myanmar to take up cause of Rohingya Muslims |url=http://www.malaysiasun.com/index.php/sid/249634427 |newspaper=Malaysia Sun |date=24 November 2016 |access-date=13 December 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220225841/http://www.malaysiasun.com/index.php/sid/249634427# |archive-date=20 December 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In December 2016, the United Nations strongly criticized the Myanmar government for its poor treatment of the Rohingya people, and called its approach "callous".<ref name=NYT-Callous>{{cite news |title=Myanmar ‘Callous’ Toward Anti-Rohingya Violence, U.N. Says |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/16/world/asia/myanmar-rohingya-violence-united-nations.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=16 December 2016 |author=Nick Cumming-Bruce |access-date=1 March 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170112002432/https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/16/world/asia/myanmar-rohingya-violence-united-nations.html# |archive-date=12 January 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-38345006 |title=UN condemns Myanmar over plight of Rohingya |author= |date=16 December 2016 |work=[[BBC]] |publisher= |access-date=21 July 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180618035906/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-38345006# |archive-date=18 June 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The United Nations also called on [[Aung San Suu Kyi]], the [[State Counsellor of Myanmar]] (''de facto'' [[head of government]]) and a [[Nobel laureate]], to take steps to stop violence against the Rohingyas.<ref name="TI-UN-Kyi"/><ref name= UN-to-Suu-Kyi/> In its report released in February 2017, the UN stated that the persecution of the Rohingya had included serious human rights violations. The UN Human Rights Commissioner [[Zeid Raad Al Hussein]] stated "The cruelty to which these Rohingya children have been subjected is unbearable – what kind of hatred could make a man stab a baby crying out for his mother's milk?"<ref name="BBC 2017" /><ref name="Al Jazeera 2017"/> A spokesperson of the government stated that the allegations were very serious, and would be investigated.<ref name="BBC 2017" />
On 23 May 2017, a report released by the military rejected the allegations made by the OHCHR in February, stating that, "Out of 18 accusations included in the OHCHR report, 12 were found to be incorrect, with the remaining six accusations found to be false and fabricated accusations based on lies and invented statements."<ref>{{cite news|title=Myanmar army rejects UN Rohingya abuse claims|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-40011437|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=BBC News|date=23 May 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170523114002/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-40011437#|archive-date=23 May 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

{{Infobox Australian Political Party | party_name = Australian Cyclists Party | party_logo =[[File:Australian_Cyclists_Party_logo.png|250px]] | party_wikicolourid = Australian Cyclists | leader = Omar Khalifa | foundation = 2013 | ideology = [[Cycling]] issues | headquarters = PO Box 460, Berry NSW 2535 | holds_government = | website = https://australian-cyclists-party.org.au/ | international = }} The '''Australian Cyclists Party''' is a minor political party in Australia.<ref name="NSW register"/> It was registered with the [[New South Wales Electoral Commission]] in 2014, and unsuccessfully contested the [[New South Wales state election, 2015|2015 New South Wales state election]]. It was also registered later with the [[Victorian Electoral Commission]], and unsuccessfully contested the [[Victorian state election, 2014|2014 Victorian state election]]. It registered with the [[Australian Electoral Commission]] for federal elections on 20 August 2014 and voluntarily deregistered on 5 September 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aec.gov.au/Parties_and_Representatives/Party_Registration/Deregistered_parties/files/2017-6296.pdf |title=Australian Cyclists Party Voluntary Deregistration |publisher=[[Australian Electoral Commission]] |date=5 September 2017 |accessdate=13 September 2017 |quote=Notice under s 135(1) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 Australian Cyclists Party was registered on 20 August 2014 and deregistered on 5 September 2017. Reason: s 135(1) – voluntary deregistration}}</ref> It remained registered for New South Wales state elections,<ref name="NSW register">{{cite web |url=http://www.elections.nsw.gov.au/candidates_and_parties/registered_political_parties/list_of_registered_parties |title=List of Registered Parties |publisher=[[New South Wales Electoral Commission]] |work=Elections.nsw.gov.au |accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref> but not Victoria.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.vec.vic.gov.au/CandidatesAndParties/CurrentRegisteredParties.html |title=Currently registered parties |publisher=[[Victorian Electoral Commission]] |accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref>
The party uses the slogan ''I Cycle, I Vote'', and aims to raise awareness of cycling-related issues.
The party's founder was Omar Khalifa, a former CEO of Bicycle New South Wales.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/australian-cyclists-party-plans-upper-house-bids-in-victoria-nsw-20131013-2vgyt.html |title=Australian Cyclists Party plans upper house bids in Victoria, NSW |accessdate=14 April 2014 |date=October 13, 2013 |first=Michael |last=O'Reilly |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]}}</ref> Khalifa was the lead candidate in the group of 15 candidates (this many are required to get a box "above the line") at the [[New South Wales state election, 2015|2015 New South Wales state election]] in the [[New South Wales Legislative Council]], coming third-last of all parties with just 0.43 percent of the vote.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/nsw-election-2015/results/lc/ LC NSW 2015 election results: ABC]</ref> The party also fielded candidates in six [[New South Wales Legislative Assembly|lower house]] electorates.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.abc.net.au/antonygreen/2015/03/summary-of-candidates-and-parties-contesting-the-2015-nsw-election.html |title=Summary of Candidates and parties Contesting the 2015 NSW Election |work=Antony Green's Election Blog |publisher=ABC |accessdate=12 April 2015}}</ref>
The Australian Cyclists Party fielded nine [[Australian Senate|senate]] candidates and two candidates for seats in the [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] in the [[Australian federal election, 2016|2016 federal election]]. The one Cyclists Party candidate in Victoria was second in Group E on the Senate ballot paper, sharing the group with the candidate for the [[Science Party (Australia)|Science Party]].<ref name="2016candidates">{{cite web |url=http://www.aec.gov.au/election/candidates.htm |title=Candidates for the 2016 federal election |date=11 June 2016 |access-date=11 June 2016 |publisher=[[Australian Electoral Commission]]}}</ref>
