''বাংলাদেশ সীমান্ত রক্ষক | colors_labels = }} The '''Border Guards Bangladesh''' ([[Bengali language|Bengali]] transliteration: বর্ডার গার্ড বাংলাদেশ; translated from English: বাংলাদেশ সীমান্ত রক্ষক; ''BGB''), formerly known as the '''Bangladesh Rifles''',{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8544160.stm | title=Bangladesh Rifles to get new name | publisher=BBC News | date=1 March 2010 | accessdate=26 April 2010}} is the oldest uniformed force in Bangladesh. It is a paramilitary force under the [[Ministry of Home Affairs (Bangladesh)|Ministry of Home Affairs]]. BGB is primarily responsible for the border security of the country, in Bangladesh the force is known as "The Vigilant Sentinels of the National Frontier".[http://bgb.gov.bd/ Bangladesh] The Present Director General is Maj. Gen. [[Md Shafeenul Islam| Shafeenul Islam]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/city/maj-gen-shafeenul-new-dg-bgb-1551307|title=Maj Gen Shafeenul new DG of BGB|publisher=The Daily Star|access-date=24 March 2018}} Border Guards Bangladesh, as a paramilitary force, is entrusted with the responsibility to defend the {{convert|4427|km}} border of Bangladesh.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KqTIhTWuAXcC&pg=PA73&lpg=PA73&dq=border+Bangladesh+4427+km&source=bl&ots=JqHez5EeqN&sig=CiHj9CaxIy0WBuvAA213lhb9740&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi_6JOQ07vTAhXLOCYKHQHhCJMQ6AEIKjAB#v=onepage&q=border%20Bangladesh%204427%20km&f=false|title=The Bengal Borderland: Beyond State and Nation in South Asia|last=Schendel|first=Willem van|date=2005-01-01|publisher=Anthem Press|year=|isbn=9781843311454|location=|pages=73|language=en}} BGB boasts a military history spanning over two centuries.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nWqsAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT90&dq=Ramgarh+Local+Battalion&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj4l7KR1LvTAhVEQCYKHYifCzYQ6AEIMzAD#v=onepage&q=Ramgarh%20Local%20Battalion&f=false|title=India’s National Security: Annual Review 2009|last=Kumar|first=Satish|date=2012-02-27|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136704901|language=en}} During peacetime this force is also responsible for anti-smuggling operations, investigating cross border crime and extending governmental authority to remote and isolated areas. From time to time BGB has also been called upon to assist the administration in the maintenance of internal law & order, relief and rehabilitation work after any kind of natural disaster.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/city/bgb-deployed-dhaka-175864|title=Dhaka jail's security boosted, BGB deployed|date=2015-11-21|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news/bgb-man-shot-dead-in-comilla|title=BGB man shot dead in Comilla|date=2013-11-26|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}} During wartime BGB comes under the control of the Ministry of Defence as an auxiliary force to the [[Bangladesh Army]]. ==History== ===Formation and pre 1947=== ==== Ramgarh Local Battalion ==== The [[Ramgarh Local Battalion]] was established on 29 June 1795 at the city of [[Ramgarh Upazila|Ramgarh]],{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BksqAQAAIAAJ&q=Ramgarh+Local+Battalion&dq=Ramgarh+Local+Battalion&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj4l7KR1LvTAhVEQCYKHYifCzYQ6AEIUjAJ|title=South Asia Defence and Strategic Year Book|last=|first=|date=2009-01-01|publisher=Panchsheel|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=273|language=en}} consisting of 486 personnel, as the "Frontier Protection Force", under the command of the [[East India Company]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bJfcCPUr0OoC&pg=PA44&lpg=PA44&dq=Ramgarh+Local+Battalion&source=bl&ots=PT8uFyDw8W&sig=rYaUl-hlxQMqPmmvLL7CWP-DRds&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiOvKCllIzSAhXFHxoKHaZGByQQ6AEIUjAJ#v=onepage&q=Ramgarh%20Local%20Battalion&f=false|title=Historical Dictionary of Bangladesh|last=Rahman|first=Syedur|date=27 April 2010|publisher=Scarecrow Press|year=|isbn=9780810874534|location=|pages=44|language=en|quote=|via=}} Later the force was converted into a paramilitary unit with its own name (Ramgarh Local Battalion) and uniform. At that time its primary responsibility was to suppress insurgent activities around the Ramgarh area. ==== Special Reserve Company ==== During 1799, the force established its first camp at [[Pilkhana, Bangladesh|Pilkhana]], where the headquarters remain to this day. The camp unit then was known as "Special Reserve Company". ==== Frontier Guards ==== The Ramgarh Local Battalion was renamed as the "Frontier Guards" and remained so for thirty years from 1861 to 1891. ==== Bengal Military Police ==== From 1891 till 1920, the Frontier Guards were re-organized and re-equipped with modern weapons and renamed once again as the "Bengal Military Police". Commanded by a [[Subedar]] (Senior Warrant Officer), the BMP had four companies located in [[Dhaka]], Dhumka and [[Gangtok]]. This force also participated in the [[First World War]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dQR6DQAAQBAJ&pg=PT190&dq=Eastern+Frontier+Rifles&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwidj9zk6LvTAhXJKCYKHfaiAUIQ6AEIKDAB#v=onepage&q=Eastern%20Frontier%20Rifles&f=false|title=Indigenous Identity in South Asia: Making Claims in the Colonial Chittagong Hill Tracts|last=Chowdhury|first=Tamina M.|date=2016-11-10|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317202929|language=en}} ==== Eastern Frontier Rifles ==== The BMP was reorganised yet once again and renamed as the "[[Eastern Frontier Rifles]]" in 1920. Its primary task was to protect the borders. It also took part in numerous military operations during the [[Second World War]]. ===East Pakistan Rifles=== After the [[partition of India]], "Eastern Frontier Rifles" was re-grouped and renamed as the "East Pakistan Rifles" in 1947.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KqTIhTWuAXcC&pg=PA108&dq=Eastern+Frontier+Rifles&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwidj9zk6LvTAhXJKCYKHfaiAUIQ6AEIQjAG#v=onepage&q=Eastern%20Frontier%20Rifles&f=false|title=The Bengal Borderland: Beyond State and Nation in South Asia|last=Schendel|first=Willem van|date=2005-01-01|publisher=Anthem Press|year=|isbn=9781843311454|location=|pages=108|language=en}} It was the primary border protection force of the then East Pakistan. A number of Metropolitan Armed Police of Calcutta and some 1,000 ex-soldiers of West Pakistan merged into this force. Officers from the army were transferred to command and reorganise EPR. In 1958, it was also assigned the anti-smuggling duties on top of its primary role as the border guards. Major [[Tufail Mohammad]] was awarded the highest military award of Pakistan, '[[Nishan-e-Haider]]', for his action in the Laksmipur Operation.{{Cite news|url=http://dunyanews.tv/en/Pakistan/348152-Maj-Tufail-Shaheed-remembered-on-his-58th-death-a|title=Maj. Tufail Shaheed remembered on his 58th death anniversary - Pakistan - Dunya News|work=dunyanews.tv|access-date=2017-04-24}}{{Cite news|url=http://nation.com.pk/national/09-Aug-2016/maj-tufail-shaheed-remembered|title=Maj Tufail Shaheed remembered|work=The Nation|access-date=2017-04-24|language=en-US}}. In 1965 India Pakistan war this force fought valiantly and successfully in a number of skirmishes in Lathitila, Dohogram, Laksmipur, Assalong and Boroibari. [[File:Bangladeshi Rifles training.jpg|thumbnail|left|A Bangladesh Rifles Senior Warrant Officer (left in yellow/green outfit) applies a mechanical advantage control/hold to a US Marine during training.]] ===Bangladesh Liberation War 1971=== During the [[Bangladesh Liberation War]] of 1971 nearly nine thousand of the members of the East Pakistan Rifles (EPR) turned against the [[Pakistan Army]], following the Declaration of Independence of Bangladesh on 26 March 1971 at Kalurghat Radio Station, Chittagong. Eight hundred and seventeen EPR personnel were subsequently reported as being killed in action. East Pakistan Rifles was the border security and anti-smuggling force stationed in what was to become independent Bangladesh. It was commanded by Junior Commissioned Officers (JCO) at the company level. All EPR companies were based within 5 miles of the international boundary. There were two senior commissioned officers, seconded from the Pakistan Army in command of each Wing (battalion) of the EPR. In March 1971, there were 12 EPR Wings. The entire force according to CIA estimates had 10 thousand enlisted personal.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2017/03/09/east-pakistan-many-pro-pakistani-army-officers/|title=East Pakistan had many pro-Pakistani army officers {{!}} Dhaka Tribune|date=2017-03-09|work=Dhaka Tribune|access-date=2017-04-24|language=en-US}} At the outbreak of [[Bangladesh Liberation War|Bangladesh Liberation war]] the EPR were the first Bengali military unit to defect from the Pakistan forces; moving to Sholashahar and the main military cantonment, while calling on all Bengali soldiers to join them. Reportedly West Pakistani officers serving with the EPR were executed by their Bengali colleagues. On 26 March, the Pakistan Army sent troops to suppress the EPR. The EPR ambushed them but the Pakistanis managed to encircle them. As a result, the EPR took heavy losses at Kumira. According to Captain Rafiq, "This ambush by the E.P.R. troops at Kumira was the first direct action against the enemy in the history of our liberation war."(Major Rafiq: A Tale of Millions, Page 56 and Aberar Shongram Shadhinotar Shongram, P:135, by: Lieutenant Colonel [[Abu Osman Chowdhury]]){{verify source|date=June 2014}} ===Bangladesh Rifles=== On 29 January 1972, the East Pakistan Rifles was renamed the Bangladesh Rifles with the officers seconded from Bangladesh Army.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bJfcCPUr0OoC&pg=PA45&dq=1972+Bangladesh+Rifles&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj_4vSi6LvTAhXILSYKHeNkCXcQ6AEIJDAA#v=onepage&q=1972%20Bangladesh%20Rifles&f=false|title=Historical Dictionary of Bangladesh|last=Rahman|first=Syedur|date=2010-04-27|publisher=Scarecrow Press|year=|isbn=9780810874534|location=|pages=45|language=en}} Bangladesh Rifles initially had 9 thousand personal in 1971 which by 1973 had increased to 20 thousand.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bm-bBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA161&dq=Bangladesh+Rifles+defense&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj_j8eB77vTAhUHeCYKHUcHCG0Q6AEIJDAA#v=onepage&q=Bangladesh%20Rifles%20defense&f=false|title=Bangladesh Country Study Guide Volume 1 Strategic Information and Developments|last=USA|first=IBP|date=2012-03-03|publisher=Lulu.com|year=|isbn=9781438773896|location=|pages=161|language=en}} Bangladesh Rifles and Indian [[Border Security Force]]s exchanged fired near the Comilla-Tripura border throughout the entire month of December 1979.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1979/12/03/archives/india-and-bangladesh-trade-fire-in-border-dispute-negotiations.html|title=India and Bangladesh Trade Fire in Border Dispute|last=Times|first=Special To The New York|date=1979-12-03|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-24|issn=0362-4331}} In 1996 Bangladesh Rifles personal had grown to 69 thousand.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RFywfJunO1wC&pg=PA38&dq=Bangladesh+Rifles+defense&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj_j8eB77vTAhUHeCYKHUcHCG0Q6AEIcTAO#v=onepage&q=Bangladesh%20Rifles%20defense&f=false|title=Bangladesh|last=Whyte|first=Mariam|last2=Yong|first2=Jui Lin|date=2009-09-01|publisher=Marshall Cavendish|year=|isbn=9780761444756|location=|pages=38|language=en}}[[File:BSF_and_BGB.JPG|thumb|BSF and BGB]] ===Bangladesh–India border clashes 2001=== The [[2001 Bangladesh–India border clashes|2001 Indian–Bangladeshi border conflict]] took place in the third week of April 2001 between companies of the Bangladesh Rifles and the Indian Border Security Force on the poorly marked international border between the two countries. This was the worst border conflict Bangladesh was involved in since Independence. The 16–19 April fighting took place around the village of Padua (known as Pyrdiwah in India), which adjoins the Indian state of [[Meghalaya]] and the Timbil area of the Bangladesh border in the Sylhet district. In that area, 6.5 kilometres of the border have remained in dispute for the past 30 years. The trigger for the clash appears to have been an attempt by Indian forces to construct a footpath from an army outpost in Padua across a disputed territory some 300 metres wide to Indian Meghalaya. On 15 April 2001, the BDR attacked and captured Pyrdiwah village. Both sides later deescalated and returned to the original positions on the border. This incident left 16 Indian [[Border Security Force]] paramilitary men dead and 3 Border Guards Bangladesh men dead with 5 other BGB troops injured.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1284789.stm|title=Fresh Bangladesh border clash|date=19 April 2001|publisher=BBC|access-date=3 April 2016}} ===BDR Mutiny 2009=== On 25 February 2009, regular [[Bangladesh Rifles revolt|BDR soldiers mutinied]] against their officers who were seconded from the Bangladesh Army.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/26/world/asia/26bangla.html|title=Army’s Border Guards Rebel in Bangladesh|last=Manik|first=Julfikar Ali|date=2009-02-25|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-24|last2=Sengupta|first2=Somini|issn=0362-4331}} The mutiny took when senior commanders were in Dhaka for convocation or durbar.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/dhaka/2017/02/25/8-years-gruesome-bdr-mutiny-still-memory/|title=8 years on, gruesome BDR mutiny still in memory {{!}} Dhaka Tribune|date=2017-02-25|work=Dhaka Tribune|access-date=2017-04-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1882554,00.html|title=After the Mutiny, Questions About Bangladesh's Army|last=Sobhan|first=Zafar|date=2009-03-02|work=Time|access-date=2017-04-24|issn=0040-781X}} A total of 74 people were killed in the Mutiny.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/14/world/asia/14bangla.html|title=Bangladeshi Premier Faces a Grim Crucible|last=Sengupta|first=Somini|date=2009-03-13|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-24|issn=0362-4331}} Many senior officers were killed, including almost the entire higher echelon of the command structure – about 57 army officers who were present in the Bangladesh Rifles' headquarters in the capital Dhaka. These included the Director General of the BDR. The soldiers mutinied due to reasons which largely remain unknown, though resentment at officers being seconded from Bangladesh army and allegations of corruption are believed to have been among the causes.{{cite web |url=http://www.bangladeshchronicle.net/index.php/2013/02/pilkhana-massacre-collaborator-mixes-in-the-crowd |title=Archived copy |accessdate=22 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307070434/http://www.bangladeshchronicle.net/index.php/2013/02/pilkhana-massacre-collaborator-mixes-in-the-crowd |archivedate=7 March 2014 |df= }}{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7910837.stm|title=Bangladesh becomes battle zone|date=25 February 2009|publisher=BBC|access-date=3 April 2016}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12123651|title=Bangladesh tries 800 soldiers for bloody 2009 mutiny|publisher=BBC News|access-date=3 April 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/02/25/bangladesh.gunbattle/index.html|title=Dozens feared dead in Bangladesh mutiny |publisher=CNN|access-date=3 April 2016}} [[File:Dahgram_BGB_Check_post_sign.jpg|thumb|Dahgram BGB Check post sign]] After 30 hours, being surrounded by Bangladesh Army tanks, the mutineers surrendered with about 6,000 of them taken under arrest, ending the mutiny.{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/07/04/bangladesh-torture-deaths-jailed-mutiny-suspects |title=Human Rights Watch Report on Bangladesh Rifles Mutiny Trial|publisher=Human Rights Watch |date=4 July 2012 |accessdate=29 June 2014}} On November 2013, Bangladesh sentenced 152 mutineers from Bangladesh Rifles to death.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/06/world/asia/152-soldiers-given-death-penalty-over-revolt-in-bangladesh.html|title=152 Bangladeshi Border Guards Get Death Penalty Over Revolt|last=Manik|first=Julfikar Ali|date=2013-11-05|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-24|last2=Barry|first2=Ellen|issn=0362-4331}} ===Border Guards Bangladesh=== In the aftermath of the mutiny, the Bangladesh Rifles was reorganised with new recruits. The force is still commanded by senior officers seconded from the Bangladesh Army. The Bangladesh Rifles have gone through some fundamental changes since 2010. It was officially renamed as the Border Guard Bangladesh (BGB) on 23 January 2011 and reorganised with fresh recruits. The BGB has a current strength of 50,000 organised into 61 battalions and largely located in numerous [[border outpost]]s (B.O.P.). Administration staff and most of the officer corps are trained by and seconded from the Bangladesh Army. However, there are around 100 officers promoted from within the force itself. The border guards also formed their own intelligence unit.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-102204|title=BDR to get new name, uniform, intelligence unit|date=2009-08-19|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}} The Border Guard Bangladesh Act, 2010 increased the maximum punishment for mutiny from 7 years in jail to the death penalty.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-155222|title=Firm fetters for border guards|date=2010-09-20|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}} ===Bangladesh–Myanmar border skirmish 2015=== On 28 May 2014, during a routine patrol of the BGB in [[Bandarban District]], along the Bangladesh-Myanmar border, [[Myanmar Border Police]] opened indiscriminate firing on the BGB patrol. The incident took the life of Border Guard Corporal Mizanur Rahman 43. The body of the slain soldier was then carried over the border by Myanmar Border Police. On 30 May upon request of the Myanmar Ambassador to Bangladesh a BGB team was waiting near border pillar no. 52 for identification of the dead body which was proposed by the Myanmar side. However, to the complete surprise of the BGB, Myanmar border forces suddenly started firing on the waiting BGB team without any provocation resulting in the BGB team returning fire. Both sides deescalated and agreed to a cease fire and on the following day Myanmar returned the dead body of BGB Corporal Mizanur Rahman. Bangladesh's Ministry of Foreign Affairs had protested strongly to the Burmese ambassador over the unprovoked eruption of gunfire by Burmese border troops.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/myanmar-returns-arms-ammo-of-slain-bgb-man-27159|title=Myanmar returns arms, ammo of slain BGB man|date=2014-06-05|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/myanmars-border-force-regrets-mizans-killing-27206|title=Myanmar's border force regrets Mizan's killing|date=2014-06-06|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}} ===Bangladesh–Arakan Army border clash 2015=== On 26 August 2015 the [[Arakan Army (Kachin State)|Arakan Army]], A separatist group in Myanmar, attack a BGB patrol in Boro Modak, [[Thanchi Upazila|Thanchi]], [[Bandarban District|Bandarban]]. Two border guards were injured in the attack. On 11 May 2015 the BGB camp in Thanchi came under mortar fire, BGB retaliated by firing two rounds towards the border.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/country/bandarban-bgb-camp-comes-under-mortar-shells-attacks-1222675|title=Bandarban BGB camp comes under mortar attack|date=2016-05-12|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}} Indian BSF agreed to allow BGB to use BSF roads in India to patrol the border on 1 August 2016.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/india-lets-bgb-use-its-roads-patrol-1262443|title=India lets BGB use its roads for patrol|date=2016-08-01|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}} On 15 November 2016 Border Guards Bangladesh stopped 86 Rohingyas from entering Bangladesh on two boats.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/coast-guards-push-back-125-rohingyas-1317412|title=Coast guards push back 125 Rohingyas|date=2016-11-20|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}} On 6 February 2017 BGB protested with their counterparts in Myanmar Border Guard Police, after they shot and killed a Bangladeshi fisherman in the [[Naf River]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/country/bangladesh-national-shot-dead-myanmar-border-1356781|title=Bangladesh national shot dead at Myanmar border|date=2017-02-06|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}} BGB deployed its first female border guards on 24 February 2017 in the [[Dinajpur District, Bangladesh|Dinajpur]] border area.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/nation/2017/02/24/first-ever-female-bgb-officers-deployed-to-hili-border/|title=First ever female BGB members deployed at Hili Border {{!}} Dhaka Tribune|date=2017-02-24|work=Dhaka Tribune|access-date=2017-04-24|language=en-US}} BGB and [[Myanmar Police Force]] came to an agreement on 6 April 2017 to remove mines from the border area.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/city/border-guard-bangladesh-myanmar-cops-agree-remove-mines-border-1387255|title=BGB, Myanmar cops agree to remove mines from border|date=2017-04-06|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-13|language=en}} ==Decorations== The then-''East Pakistan Rifles'' joined the [[Bangladesh War of Independence]] on the side of [[Mukti Bahini]] in 1971. One hundred and forty one members earned gallantry awards for their outstanding contribution to the liberation war of Bangladesh. [[Nur Mohammad Sheikh|Naik Nur Mohammad Sheikh]] and [[Munshi Abdur Rouf|Naik Munshi Abdur Rouf]] posthumously earned the [[Bir Sreshtha]], which is the highest gallantry award of the nation.{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Rauf,_Birsrestha_Munshi_Abdur|title=Rauf, Birsrestha Munshi Abdur - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-24}}{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Sheikh,_Birsrestha_Nur_Mohammad|title=Sheikh, Birsrestha Nur Mohammad - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-24}} 8 earned the [[Bir Uttom]]. 40 earned the [[Bir Bikram]] and 91 earned the [[Bir Protik]] awards. After independence, on 3 March 1972 the force had been renamed as Bangladesh Rifles. As a mark of recognition for the courage and bravery of its members, BDR introduced '[[Bangladesh Rifles Podok]]' in 1985 and [[President Rifles podok]]' in 1989.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-120045|title=Birth of the Phoenix|date=2010-01-02|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-24|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-26032|title=CA asks BDR to plan for creating poll atmosphere|date=2008-03-04|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-24|language=en}} 21 members had received the 'Bangladesh Rifles Podok' 29 had received the 'President Rifles Podok'. ==Responsibilities== * Patrolling and securing the border * Investigating cross border crimes * Anti-smuggling Operations * Counter Terrorism * Domestic law enforcement during national emergencies * Acting as a reserve force under M.O.D. during war == List of Chiefs of Border Guards Bangladesh == {{Main|Director General of Bangladesh Border Guards}} ==Organization== The BGB is commanded by a [[Major General]] ranked [[Bangladesh Army]] officer. The BGB administration and most of the officer corps are trained and deputed from the Bangladesh Army. There are, however, around 100 officers who are promoted from within the force itself. They can be promoted as high as Deputy Director (Equivalent to Major in Bangladesh Army). Its current strength is 50,000 structured along 63 battalions and numerous border outposts (B.O.P.), mostly along the borders. BGB is organised into a central headquarters and 4 regional headquarters. Under the regional headquarters there are 16 sectors. * '''Central HQ''': [[Pilkhana, Bangladesh|Pilkhana]], [[Dhaka]] ** Director-General (DG): *** Additional Director-General (Headquarters) *** Additional Director General (Operations and Training) *** Additional Director General (Administration) *** Additional Director General (Medical) *** Additional Director General (Border Security Bureau) *** Additional Director General (Border Guard Training Centre and College) *** Deputy Director General (Records) *** Deputy Director General (Logistics) *** Deputy Director General (Budget) *** Deputy Director General (Central Purchase) *** Deputy Director General (Construction Works) *** Deputy Director General (Communications) *** Sector Command ([[Dhaka]]) *** HQ Battalion *** ICT Battalion ** '''North Eastern Regional HQ''': [[Sarail Upazila|Sarail]] *** Sector Command ([[Comilla]]) *** Sector Command ([[Mymensingh]]) *** Sector Command ([[Srimangal]]) *** Sector Command ([[Sylhet]]) *** Regional Intelligence Bureau ([[Sarail Upazila|Sarail]]) ** '''North Western Regional HQ''': [[Rangpur Division|Rangpur]] *** Sector Command ([[Dinajpur District, Bangladesh|Dinajpur]]): *** Sector Command ([[Rajshahi]]) *** Sector Command ([[Rangpur Division|Rangpur]]) *** Sector Command ([[Thakurgaon District|Thakurgaon]]) *** Regional Intelligence Bureau ([[Rangpur Division|Rangpur]]) ** '''South Eastern Regional HQ''': [[Halishahar]] *** Sector Command ([[Guimara]]) *** Sector Command ([[Bandarban]]) *** Sector Command ([[Chittagong|Chattagram]]) *** Sector Command ([[Khagrachari]]) *** Sector Command ([[Rangamati]]) *** Regional Intelligence Bureau ([[Halishahar]]) ** '''South Western Regional HQ''': [[Jessore]] *** Sector Command ([[Kushtia]]) *** Sector Command ([[Khulna]]) *** Regional Intelligence Bureau ([[Jessore]]) ** '''Adhoc Region HQ - Ramu''' ==Equipment== {| class="wikitable" style="width:90%;" |- ! style="width:15%;"| Name ! style="width:18%;"| Type ! style="width:7%;"| Caliber ! style="width:40%;"| Notes |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|[[QSZ-92|Type 92]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| [[Semi-automatic pistol]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| 9mm || Standard issue sidearm. |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|[[Type 54]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| [[Semi-automatic pistol]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| 7.62mm || Chinese version of Soviet [[TT pistol|Tokarev TT-33]] in service with all branches of armed, para-military and law enforcement services. |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|[[Type 81 Assault Rifle|BD-08]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| [[Assault rifle]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| 7.62mm || Produced under license by [[Bangladesh Ordnance Factories|BOF]]. |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|[[Dragunov sniper rifle|Type 85]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| [[Sniper rifle]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| 7.62mm || |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|[[Chinese Type 81 Assault Rifle#Variants|BD-08]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| [[Light machine gun]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| 7.62mm || Produced under license by [[Bangladesh Ordnance Factories|BOF]]. |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|[[RPD]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| [[Light machine gun]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| 7.62mm || |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|[[Rheinmetall MG 3]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| [[General purpose machine gun]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| 7.62mm || |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|Type 63-1 ||! style="text-align: center;"|[[Mortar (weapon)|Mortar]] ||! style="text-align: center;"|60 mm|| Being replaced by Type 93. |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|[[M29 mortar|M 29A1]] ||! style="text-align: center;"|[[Mortar (weapon)|Mortar]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| 81mm || |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|[[RPG-7]] ||! style="text-align: center;"|[[Rocket-propelled grenade]] ||! style="text-align: center;"| 40mm || |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|[[Otokar Cobra]] ||! style="text-align: center;"|[[Armoured fighting vehicle|LAV]] || || A 4x4 wheeled LAV. 17 Received in 2008. |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|[[Mil Mi-17]] ||! style="text-align: center;"|[[Helicopter]] || || 2 on order. |- | ! style="text-align: center;"|Akshay class ||! style="text-align: center;"|Coastal Patrol Craft || || 1 ship (''BGB Shah Jalal''){{Cite web|url=https://www.vesselfinder.com/vessels/BDR-SHAHJALAL-IMO-8106472|title=BDR-SHAHJALAL - Patrol Vessel - Details and current position IMO 8106472 MMSI 0 {{!}} Vessels {{!}} VesselFinder|website=www.vesselfinder.com|language=en|access-date=2017-04-23}} |} ==Future modernization programme== BGB has adopted a long term modernization plan named "BGB Goal 2041" in 2017. The plan intends to make BGB a well-trained, well-equipped and technologically advanced force. In short terms, BGB plans for structural and manpower expansion. A new region (equivalent to [[Division (military)|division]]) will be raised in [[Ramu]] of [[Cox's Bazar]]. Three new sectors (equivalent to [[brigade]]) will be raised at [[Ali Kadam Upazila|Ali Kadam]] of [[Bandarban]], [[Naogaon]] and [[Jessore]]. Eight new [[battalion]]s will be formed at [[Jhikargacha Upazila|Jhikargacha]] of [[Jessore]], [[Meherpur]], [[Khagrachari]], ''Boro Mowdok'' of [[Bandarban]], [[Gazipur]], [[Narayanganj]] and [[Kulaura Upazila|Kulaura]] of [[Maulavibazar]]. Two riverine battalions will be raised in BGB at ''Nildumur'' of [[Shatkhira]] and [[Teknaf Upazila|Teknaf]] of [[Cox's Bazar]]. They are the first two units of BGB who will be able to operate in riverine borders and ''char''s ([[River island]]). The number of personnel will be increased from 50000 to 65000 soon. 124 ''Border Out Posts (BOP)'' and 70 heli-support BOPs are being set up in the border areas of hilly districts along the border with Myanmar. 128 ''Border Sentri Posts (BSP)'' are being constructed between the distant BOPs. BGB members ae being equipped with [[bulletproof vest]]s and [[Combat helmet|ballistic helmet]].{{cite web| url=http://www.thedailystar.net/country/prime-minister-sheikh-hasina-asks-border-guard-bangladesh-bgb-members-to-be-imbued-with-bonding-spirit-1507783| title=PM asks BGB members to be imbued with bonding spirit| publisher=The Daily Star| date=21 December 2017| accessdate=21 December 2017}} A ''Quick Response Force'' will be established for BGB. The force will work to supply modern arms and ammunition swiftly to border points in case of any emergency.{{cite web| url=http://m.theindependentbd.com/printversion/details/107551| title=BGB to introduce Quick Reaction Force| publisher=The Independent| date=4 August 2017| accessdate=13 August 2017}} For smooth operation in the border areas, border roads are being constructed. In ''BGB day 2017'', prime minister said that the government has undertaken a plan to construct a total of 3,167 km ring road across the borders with India and Myanmar. BGB intends to go three dimensional as per the plan. Bangladesh government has already approved the proposal for buying two [[Mil Mi-17|Mi-171E]] helicopters from Russia at a cost of Tk. 355.10 crore.{{cite web| url=http://m.theindependentbd.com/post/169673| title=Russian copters to turn BGB into 3-dimensional force | publisher=The Independent| date=9 October 2018| accessdate=13 October 2018}} However, [[Bangladesh Air Force]] pilots will fly the helicopters initially. A [[heliport]] with hanger is being set up at ''Baitul Izzat'' in [[Chittagong]]. Eventually, BGB plans to have four aviation wings.{{cite web| url=http://m.theindependentbd.com/post/55620| title=BGB wants aviation wing | publisher=The Independent| date=13 August 2016| accessdate=13 August 2017}} To effectively monitor the border, BGB plans to add modern technology to the border management. The plan is to set up [[camera]]s, [[Night vision device|night vision goggles]] and [[Infrared detector|infrared sensors]] throughout the border. BGB plans to achieve 3I (Information, Identification, Intervention) capabilities in the border in long term. Having [[Radar]] and [[Satellite]] monitoring facilities in the border are also planned. ==References== {{reflist|30em}}{{commons category|Border Guards Bangladesh}} {{Bangladesh topics}} {{Military of Bangladesh}} {{Border guards}} [[Category:Military of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Bangladesh Liberation War]] [[Category:Borders of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Paramilitary forces of Bangladesh]] [[Category:1795 establishments in the British Empire]] [[Category:Government agencies of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Border Guards Bangladesh]] [[Category:Uniformed services of Bangladesh]]

'''Candelilla wax''' is a [[wax]] derived from the leaves of the small [[Candelilla]] shrub native to northern Mexico and the southwestern United States, ''Euphorbia cerifera'' and ''[[Euphorbia antisyphilitica]]'', from the family ''[[Euphorbiaceae]]''. It is yellowish-brown, hard, brittle, aromatic, and opaque to translucent.
== Composition and production== With a [[melting point]] of 68.5–72.5 °C, candelilla wax consists of mainly [[hydrocarbon]]s (about 50%, chains with 29–33 carbons), [[ester]]s of higher molecular weight (20–29%), free acids (7–9%), and [[resin]]s (12–14%, mainly [[triterpenoid]] esters). The high hydrocarbon content distinguishes this wax from [[carnauba wax]].<ref name=Ullmann>Uwe Wolfmeier,Hans Schmidt, Franz-Leo Heinrichs, Georg Michalczyk, Wolfgang Payer,Wolfram Dietsche, Klaus Boehlke, Gerd Hohner, Josef Wildgruber "Waxes" in Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Wiley-VCH, Weinheim, 2002. {{DOI|10.1002/14356007.a28_103}}</ref> It is insoluble in water, but soluble in many organic [[solvent]]s such as [[acetone]], [[chloroform]], [[benzene]], and [[Turpentine]].
The wax is obtained by boiling the leaves and stems with dilute [[sulfuric acid]], and the resulting "cerote" is skimmed from the surface and further processed. In this way, about 900 tons are produced annually<sup>.<ref name=Ullmann/>
== Uses == It is mostly used mixed with other waxes to harden them without raising their melting point. As a [[food additive]], candelilla wax has the [[E number]] E 902 and is used as a [[glazing agent]]. It also finds use in [[Cosmetics|cosmetic]] industry, as a component of [[lip balm]]s and lotion bars. One of its major uses is as a [[binder (material)|binder]] for [[chewing gum]]s.
Candelilla wax can be used as a substitute for [[carnauba wax]] and [[beeswax]]. It is also used for making [[varnish]].
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.fao.org/ag/agn/jecfa-additives/specs/Monograph1/Additive-100.pdf Candelilla wax data sheet] - from the UN Food and Agriculture Organization * [http://www.inchem.org/documents/jecfa/jecmono/v30je12.htm Candelilla wax (WHO food additives series 30)] * [http://www.candelilla.org/ Candelilla Institute] * [http://www.texasbeyondhistory.net/waxcamps/index.html Wax, Men, and Money]:Candelilla Wax Camps along the Rio Grande

The old city lies beyond.
| map = United Kingdom Bristol Central | map_width = 240 | map_caption = [[File:Red pog.svg|8px]] Castle Park shown within Bristol | map_alt = | map_label = Castle Park | map_label_position = right | relief = | mark = | grid_ref_UK = ST592731 | grid_ref_Ireland = | coords = {{coord|51.4558|N|2.5881|W|region:GB|format=dec|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = | type = | location = | nearest_city = | area = | elevation = | created = 1977 | designer = | etymology = | operator = Bristol City Council | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_ref = | status = | awards = | open = | camp_sites = | hiking_trails = | other_info = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} -->
|child = |embedded = }} '''Castle Park''' (sometimes referred to as '''Castle Green''') is a public open space in [[Bristol]], England, managed by [[Bristol City Council]]. It is bounded by the [[Floating Harbour]] and Castle Street to the south, Lower Castle Street to the east, and Broad Weir, Newgate and [[Wine Street, Bristol|Wine Street]] to the north. Its western boundary is less obviously defined and has been the subject of controversy, perhaps because the area around [[High Street, Bristol|High Street]] and [[St Mary le Port Church, Bristol|St Mary le Port Church]], though not part of the park and always intended for development, is often considered at the same time as the park.<ref name="ffbparks">{{cite book |title=The Fight for Bristol |first1=Gordon |last1=Priest |first2=Pamela |last2=Cobb |year=1980 |chapter=Open spaces |publisher=Bristol Civic Society and The Redcliffe Press}}</ref>
Opened on 30 September 1978,<ref name="ffbparks"/> the park occupies the site of what was once Bristol's main shopping district. The area was largely destroyed by the [[Luftwaffe]] during the [[Bristol Blitz|Blitz]], and that which remained was subsequently demolished. In the years since the end of the Second World War, Castle Park has become home to a number of anti-fascist memorials.
The ruined tower of [[St Mary le Port Church, Bristol|St Mary-le-Port Church]] stands to the west of the park, surrounded by derelict financial office buildings. Adjoining the ruins of [[St Peter's Church, Castle Park, Bristol|St Peter's Church]] in the middle of the park is a sensory herb garden, and five silver birch trees as a memorial to the beaches of the [[D-Day landings]]. To the east is a grassy arena, and the partially excavated remains of [[Bristol Castle]] with a preserved vaulted chamber. There is also a bandstand and a children's play area.
Tree-lined St Peter's Square, to the north of St Peter's church, has been home to various events including German Christmas markets.<ref name="germarket">{{cite news |url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/German-Christmas-market-opens-Bristol/story-11312441-detail/story.html |title=German Christmas market opens in Bristol |work=This is Bristol |accessdate=12 November 2011 |date=20 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130421121710/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/German-Christmas-market-opens-Bristol/story-11312441-detail/story.html |archivedate=21 April 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In recent summers a tethered balloon has been placed near the bandstand, offering ascents to sightseers.
Recent attempts to develop the area between the park's western edge and High Street have proved controversial; Bristol City Council are keen to replace derelict buildings with a [[mixed-use development]] to help reconnect the Old City to [[Broadmead]] and raise funds to improve the park; others would rather see the park extended to High Street.
==History== [[File:Cat and Wheel tavern, Castle Green Bristol.jpg|thumb|upright|Cat and Wheel Tavern, corner of Castle Green and Peter Street, in about 1888]] [[File:Castle Green Bristol.jpg|thumb|upright|Cock and Bottle Lane seen from Castle Green in the late 19th century]] The town of Bristol was settled at some time in the [[Anglo-Saxon]] period on the northern or [[Mercia]]n side of a crossing point of the [[River Avon (Bristol)|River Avon]], at or near to the present [[Bristol Bridge]]. The town lay entirely between the Avon and the [[River Frome, Bristol|Frome]], which at that time emerged into the Avon just downstream of Bristol Bridge.<ref name="little">{{cite book |title=The Story of Bristol |first=Bryan |last=Little |publisher=Redcliffe Press |year=1991 |page=6 |isbn=1-872971-40-7}}</ref>
Archaeological excavations of the area in 1962-1963 suggest that the original settlement was centred to the east of St Peter's Church, with Mary-le-Port on its western limit. The building of Bristol Castle in the latter part of the 11th century resulted in the focus of the settlement being moved to the west, where it developed into a symmetrical plan centred on the crossroads of High Street, Wine Street, [[Broad Street, Bristol|Broad Street]] and [[Corn Street]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Mary-le-Port Bristol Excavations 1962/3 |first1=Lorna |last1=Watts |first2=Philip |last2=Rahtz |publisher=City of Bristol Museums and Art Gallery |year=1985 |isbn=0-900199-26-1}}</ref> The area around Mary-le-Port Street was thus the most ancient part of the mediaeval city. [[Bristol Castle]] was home to the Norman garrison, and was a massive structure whose keep was comparable to that of the Tower of London. The castle occupied the whole of the eastern end of today's Castle park, from just east of St Peter's Church to Lower Castle Street.<ref name="dottyb">{{cite book |last=Brown |first=Dorothy |title=Bristol and how it grew |page=3 |year=1974 |publisher=Bristol Visual & Environmental Group, with the help of a grant from the South West Arts Association |location=Bristol |isbn=0-9504648-2-1 }}</ref>
In 1612 [[Robert Aldworth]], Mayor of Bristol, rebuilt [[St Peter's Hospital, Bristol|St Peter's Hospital]] on a site between St Peter's Church and the Floating Harbour. This 'beautiful house with its elaborate carving' became the Bristol Mint in 1695, and was considered to be Bristol's greatest architectural loss of the Second World War.<ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol as it Was 1939-1914 (5th Edition) |first=Reece |last=Winstone |year=1978 |publisher=Reece Winstone |page=16 |isbn=0-900814-54-3 |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol's Earliest Photographs |first=Reece |last=Winstone |year=1978 |publisher=Reece Winstone |page=44 |isbn=0-900814-32-2 |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref>
By the 16th century the castle was 'tending to ruin', and following his victory in the [[English Civil War]] [[Oliver Cromwell]] decreed its destruction in 1655, a process which was completed within a fortnight.<ref>{{cite book |title=Chilcott's descriptive history of Bristol |first=John |last=Chilcott |publisher=J Chilcott |year=1826}}</ref> The castle had stood on the main route from Bristol to London, and following its destruction a commercial avenue opened along Castle Street from the mediaeval city towards [[Old Market, Bristol|Old Market]]. The demolition of Lawford's Gate at the eastern end of Old Market Street extended this into West Street, creating an uninterrupted route into the bustling heart of Bristol.<ref name="charappr">{{cite web |url=https://www.bristol.gov.uk/documents/20182/33832/old-market-character-appraisal-red-2.pdf/be5c0518-7d70-4604-9f34-9fbc49169c3e |title=Conservation area 16 – Old Market – Character appraisal |publisher=Bristol City Council |date=July 2008 |accessdate=27 October 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304081134/https://www.bristol.gov.uk/documents/20182/33832/old-market-character-appraisal-red-2.pdf/be5c0518-7d70-4604-9f34-9fbc49169c3e |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Wine Street and Castle Street became the main shopping streets, where retailers such as [[Boots UK|Boots]], Jones's (later to become part of the [[Debenhams]] group), the [[The Co-operative brand|Co-op]] and [[Marks & Spencer]] traded. Baker Baker had large stores in Bridge Street, Wine Street and [[Mary le Port Street, Bristol|Mary le Port Street]];<ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol & Co |first=Helen |last=Reid |year=1987 |publisher=Redcliffe Press |isbn=0-948265-61-2}}</ref> two of these were connected by a high bridge across Mary-le-Port Street.<ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol Blitzed |first=Reece |last=Winstone |year=1973 |publisher=Reece Winstone |page=30 |isbn=0-900814-43-8 |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref> The area also hosted a cinema (the News Theatre) and its narrow winding back-streets contained many independent shops, hotels, and pubs.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/brizzlebornandbred/tags/streetplan |title=brizzle born and bred's photostream/Tags/streetplan |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629162442/http://www.flickr.com/photos/brizzlebornandbred/tags/streetplan |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> At the corner of High Street and Wine Street stood the 'most loved fragment of Old Bristol': The [[The Dutch House, Bristol|Dutch House]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol Blitzed |first=Reece |last=Winstone |year=1973 |publisher=Reece Winstone |page=26 |isbn=0-900814-43-8 |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref>
===Bombing of 24 November 1940=== {{See also|Bristol Blitz}} On the afternoon of 24 November 1940, 148 aircraft of the [[Luftwaffe]] left airfields in Northern France heading for Bristol. The concentration point was to be the [[Bristol Harbour|City Docks]], and their objective was to destroy Bristol's industry and port facilities. 135 aircraft reached the target area, and dropped {{convert|156,250|kg|lb|abbr=on}} of high explosives, {{convert|4,750|kg|lb|abbr=on}} of oil bombs and 12,500 incendiaries. As the raid progressed, the fires could be seen from {{convert|250|km|mi}} away. Wide areas of the city were struck, but the most concentrated damage occurred in the area between Broad Quay and [[Old Market, Bristol|Old Market]] where fierce fires burnt through the night. By the morning, 200 Bristolians were dead and 689 injured, four Luftwaffe crewmen were dead, one injured and four captured, two aircraft were lost, and a large part of the historic heart of Bristol was a smouldering ruin.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fishponds.org.uk/luftbri1.html |title=The Luftwaffe over the Bristol area 1940-44, page 1 |work=Fishponds Local History Society |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719051036/http://fishponds.org.uk/luftbri1.html |archivedate=19 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The destruction was not total, however. Post-war photographs show that buildings survived intact on Bridge Street,<ref name="1940s">{{cite book |title=Bristol in the 1940s |first=Reece |last=Winstone |publisher=Reece Winstone |year=1980 |page=51 |isbn=0-900814-61-6 |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref> High Street,<ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol as it Was 1950-1953 |first=Reece |last=Winstone |publisher=Reece Winstone |year=1980 |page=43 |isbn=0-900814-60-8 |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref> Castle Street <ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol as it Was 1950-1953 |first=Reece |last=Winstone |publisher=Reece Winstone |year=1980 |page=13 |isbn=0-900814-60-8 |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref> and Peter Street.<ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol as it Was 1953-1956 |first=Reece |last=Winstone |publisher=Reece Winstone |year=1979 |page=24 |isbn=0-900814-56-X |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref> The west end of Narrow Wine Street, a 'fantastic little old thoroughfare',<ref>{{cite book |title=English Journey |first=J.B. |last=Priestley |page=26 |year=1934 |publisher=Heinemann}}</ref> was more or less intact; Castle Mill Street and Castle Green received little damage,<ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol as it Was 1953-1956 |first=Reece |last=Winstone |publisher=Reece Winstone |year=1979 |page=27 |isbn=0-900814-56-X |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref> and Upper, Middle and Lower Terrace survived.<ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol as it Was 1953-1956 |first=Reece |last=Winstone |publisher=Reece Winstone |year=1979 |page=28 |isbn=0-900814-56-X |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref> More importantly, the irreplaceable mediaeval street plan remained.
===Replanning=== [[File:Castle Green and Broadmead redevelopment - geograph.org.uk - 541958.jpg|Redevelopment around Castle Green and Broadmead, viewed from the [[River Avon (Bristol)|River Avon]]|thumb]] The idea that Bristol's main shopping area should be moved away from the Castle Street and Wine Street area was first proposed to Bristol Corporation's Planning and Reconstruction Committee by the Multiple Traders' Federation (MTF), representing the larger retailers and chain-stores, in October 1943. They suggested that the pre-war shopping area should be set aside as a civic area with perhaps a concert hall or similar building and an open space, and that the central shopping area should be moved to a less-constrained site. This suggestion formed part of the City Engineer's Master Plan of February 1944, which envisaged that the area would contain a limited number of buildings such as a conference hall, with underground parking for 2,000 cars. The removal of the shopping area was considered desirable because the fire that had destroyed so much of the area was in large part sustained by its congested nature, and in any case many of the chain-stores represented by the MTF wanted larger sites.<ref name="has6">{{cite book |title=Replanning the blitzed city centre |first=Junichi |last=Hasegawa |chapter=6 Replanning the city centre: Bristol 1940-45 |publisher=Open University Press |year=1992 |isbn=0-335-15633-9}}</ref>
The main objection to this plan came from the independent traders who did not wish to relocate because they felt that the proposed new shopping area was 'off the beaten track'.<ref name="has6" /> This objection was not unreasonable, as in its pre-war topography Bristol had a long shopping axis that started at Stapleton Road to the east, passed through [[Old Market, Bristol|Old Market]] into Castle Street, Wine Street, and [[St Nicholas Market|the City Markets]], and then via [[The Centre, Bristol|The Centre]] and [[Park Street, Bristol|Park Street]] to Queens Road and [[Whiteladies Road]]. Moving the central shopping area would break this axis. There was also concern about the serious negative social and economic impacts of 'sterilising' such a large area in the centre of the city.<ref name="has6" /> However, when the Bristol Retail Traders Federation, representing the small traders, produced a poll showing that 13,000 people wished to retain the shopping centre on its current site whereas only 400 preferred to see it moved, the local Labour party dismissed the poll describing it as 'undemocratic' and comparing the Federation's methods to those of Hitler.<ref>{{cite book |title=Replanning the blitzed city centre |first=Junichi |last=Hasegawa |chapter=7 City planning in the immediate aftermath of war: 1946 |publisher=Open University Press |year=1992 |isbn=0-335-15633-9}}</ref>
By 1966, the shops had been rebuilt in 'barren' Broadmead (at the expense of demolishing an area of [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]], [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]] and [[Tudor architecture|Tudor]] buildings that had escaped the wartime bombing more or less unscathed),<ref name="ffbsetscene">{{cite book |title=The Fight for Bristol |first1=Gordon |last1=Priest |first2=Pamela |last2=Cobb |year=1980 |chapter=Setting the Scene: Planning in Bristol since 1945 |publisher=Bristol Civic Society and The Redcliffe Press}}</ref> and the Wine Street and Castle Street area was being used for car parking.<ref name="ffbparks" /> The picturesque area around Narrow Wine Street and Castle Mill Street had been demolished to create modern Newgate, and Old Market, severed from Bristol's shopping axis by the new Temple Way Underpass and the destruction of Castle Street, was in serious decline.<ref name="ffburbren">{{cite book |title=The Fight for Bristol |first1=Gordon |last1=Priest |first2=Pamela |last2=Cobb |year=1980 |chapter=Urban renewal |publisher=Bristol Civic Society and The Redcliffe Press}}</ref> The plan for Castle Park was crystallising, however. The ruined St Peter's Church would be surrounded by a museum and an art gallery; to the east of this there would be an arts centre and the remaining area east to Lower Castle Street would be a park. The south-western corner nearest [[Bristol Bridge]] would contain a riverside hotel, and the north-western corner would be home to 'a block for cultural, professional and exhibition purposes'.<ref name="ffbparks" />
In the event, the north-western corner was leased to the Bank of England and [[Norwich Union|Norwich Union Insurance]] (whose offices now stand derelict), and the critical corner site where the Dutch House had stood was replaced by a link road to a short section of dual-carriageway linking High Street with Wine Street.<ref name="ffbparks" /> Plans for a civic centre were dropped as being too expensive.
Finally, in 1977, work began on an emasculated version of the new park. This was designed by Bristol City Council's parks department and, largely for financial reasons, it contained few of the features intended by earlier plans<ref name="ffbparks" /> but was much larger than that originally planned. The last remaining vestiges of the mediaeval street plan, Dolphin Street and Peter Street, were buried.
===Mary-le-Port development=== [[File:St Mary le Port tower Bristol.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Tower of ruined St Mary le Port with derelict building in foreground |St Mary-le-Port church, surrounded by dereliction]] In 2006, Bristol City Council announced its intention to redevelop the area to the west of Castle Park, known as the 'Mary-le-Port' site. These plans encompassed the by then derelict financial buildings, and the area to the west of St Peter's church, about 5% of the park.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/7758439.stm |title=Inquiry to look at park's future |work=British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=1 March 2011 |date=1 December 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206090350/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/7758439.stm |archivedate=6 December 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It was to be a {{convert|400,000|sqft|m2}} mixed-use development to 'regenerate this historic heart of Bristol'<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deeleyfreed.co.uk |title=St Mary-le-Port, Bristol |accessdate=1 March 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060514235036/http://www.deeleyfreed.co.uk/ |archivedate=14 May 2006 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and to 'improve connections between Broadmead, the Old City and Redcliffe' and 'enhance the setting of St Mary-le-Port church'.<ref name="reconsider">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/6156628.stm |title=Plans for city park reconsidered |work=British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=1 March 2011 |date=16 November 2006}}</ref> The council selected Deeley Freed as its preferred developer. The scheme provoked opposition from park users who felt that any reduction in the area of the park was not acceptable. 'Surprised by the extent of feeling', Bristol City Council decided to revise the plans.<ref name="reconsider" /> Campaigners then applied to have 'Town Green' status applied to the park, but this was declined in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |title=Town and Village Greens |url=http://www.bristolparksforum.org.uk/BristolTG.pdf |publisher=Bristol Parks Forum |accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref>
In 2010, the Mary-le-Port site was listed as being 'for sale' by Bristol City Council.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/news/City-plot-sales-net-163-50m/article-2342360-detail/article.html |title=Bristol City Council plot sales could net £50million if it sells four sites in centre |work=Bristol Evening Post |accessdate=1 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626141600/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/news/City-plot-sales-net-163-50m/article-2342360-detail/article.html |archivedate=26 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Castle Bridge=== [[File:Castle Bridge.jpg|thumb|Castle Bridge]] In March 2016, Bristol City Council approved plans for an S-shaped footbridge over the Floating Harbour, linking the park to the [[Finzels Reach]] development.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-31960073 |title=Finzels Reach bridge plans approved despite concerns |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=19 March 2016 |accessdate=6 July 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161001184502/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-31960073 |archivedate=1 October 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It was opened on 6 April 2017. The next day, it was announced that the bridge was named Castle Bridge by local singer Barry Walsh.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/bristol-news/bristols-newest-bridge-named-opened-19632|title=Bristol's newest bridge is named and opened to the public for the first time|last=Clensy|first=David|date=2017-04-07|website=Bristol Post|access-date=2018-01-22|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123072418/http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/bristol-news/bristols-newest-bridge-named-opened-19632|archivedate=23 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Sites of interest== [[File:Bristol Castle remains.jpg|thumb|left|The remains of Bristol Castle, landscaped in 2018 to allow public access]] Very little of [[Bristol Castle]] remains above ground. The most tangible survival is a vaulted chamber of the King's Hall, formerly on Tower Street near the now-truncated Castle Street.<ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol Today |first=Reece |last=Winstone |publisher=Reece Winstone |year=1971 |page=16 |isbn=0-900814-37-3 |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref> Other than that, the excavated remains of the south wall can be seen near the landing stage, and near St Peter's Church the [[sally port]] and traces of the west wall are visible.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.about-bristol.co.uk/old-02.asp |title=Open Spaces — Castle Park |work=About Bristol |accessdate=7 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070726114027/http://www.about-bristol.co.uk/old-02.asp |archivedate=26 July 2007 |df= }}</ref> The foundations of the keep are on show next to the public toilets on Newgate.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/brizzlebornandbred/2057133210/ |title=Map Castle Park — Bristol After the blitz |accessdate=1 March 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629162451/http://www.flickr.com/photos/brizzlebornandbred/2057133210/ |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[File:St Peter's Castle Park memorial.jpg|thumb|Memorials to Bristolians killed during the Blitz on St Peter's Church]] The park contains a number of memorials.<ref name=peace>{{cite web | url= http://www.vortex.uwe.ac.uk/places_of_peace/castle.htm | work= Places of Peace | title= Bristol : Castle Park | publisher= [[Arts and Humanities Research Council]] | accessdate= 7 March 2011 | deadurl= no | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111006190518/http://www.vortex.uwe.ac.uk/places_of_peace/castle.htm | archivedate= 6 October 2011 | df= dmy-all }}</ref> The ruins of St Peter's Church are a memorial to the civilians and auxiliary personnel killed in the [[Bristol Blitz|aerial bombing of Bristol]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.about-bristol.co.uk/chu-03.asp |title=Churches — St Peter |work=About Bristol |accessdate=1 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626195231/http://www.about-bristol.co.uk/chu-03.asp |archivedate=26 June 2007 |df= }}</ref> and a plaque on its wall lists their names.<ref name="abcp">{{cite web|url=http://www.about-bristol.co.uk/prk-04.asp |title=Open spaces — Castle Park |work=About Bristol |accessdate=7 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070820004039/http://www.about-bristol.co.uk/prk-04.asp |archivedate=20 August 2007 |df= }}</ref> Adjoining the church is a [[Sensory garden|sensory herb garden]] and The Normandy Garden of Peace, which was opened on 5 November 1995, with five [[Betula pendula|Silver Birch trees]], managed by Bristol's [[Normandy landings|D-Day]] veterans,<ref name=trees>{{cite news |url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/news/Peace-garden-vandalism-shocks-veterans/article-539841-detail/article.html |title=Peace garden vandalism shocks veterans |work=Bristol Evening Post |accessdate=7 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130505062816/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/news/Peace-garden-vandalism-shocks-veterans/article-539841-detail/article.html |archivedate=5 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> in memory of the five D-Day beaches. There are also memorial trees for [[Anne Frank]] and the victims of the [[atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki]].<ref name=peace/><ref name=trees/>
The park also contains a memorial plaque dedicated to citizens from Bristol who died fighting against the [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalist]] forces during the [[Spanish Civil War]], framed by a mosaic composed of the colours of the [[Flag of the Second Spanish Republic|flag]] of the Second Spanish Republic.<ref>https://www.iwm.org.uk/memorials/item/memorial/3159</ref><ref>https://www.warmemorialsonline.org.uk/memorial/152065</ref>
The ruined tower of St Mary-le-Port church, subject of a painting by [[John Piper (artist)|John Piper]] that appeared on a 1968 1[[Shilling (British coin)|s]]. 6[[Penny (British pre-decimal coin)|d]]. [[postage stamp]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bfdc.co.uk/1968/british_paintings_1968/oval_frame.html |title=British Paintings 1968, Oval Frame First Day Cover |work=BFDC |accessdate=3 July 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905122301/http://www.bfdc.co.uk/1968/british_paintings_1968/oval_frame.html |archivedate=5 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ViewWork?workid=11927&roomid=3955 |title=St Mary le Port, Bristol 1940 |work=Tate Collection |accessdate=7 March 2011}}</ref> stands on the western edge of the park,<ref>{{cite book |title=Bristol Today |first=Reece |last=Winstone |publisher=Reece Winstone |year=1971 |page=14 |isbn=0-900814-37-3 |authorlink=Reece Winstone}}</ref> surrounded by now-derelict buildings.
{{clear left}}
== Listed buildings==
Castle Park contains a number of listed buildings and scheduled monuments: {|class="wikitable sortable" style="width:768px" ! width="80px" |Grid ref ! width="80px" |Grade ! width="120px" |Year listed ! width="*" |Description |- |ST 58992 73026 |Scheduled monument |1949 (amended 2009) |[[St Mary le Port Church, Bristol|St Mary-le-Port Church]]<ref>{{National Heritage List for England|num=1021385|desc=St Mary-le-Port Church|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref> |- |ST 58980 73017 |II |1959 |Tower of church of St Mary-le-Port<ref>{{National Heritage List for England|num=1208338|desc=Tower of church of St Mary-le-Port|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref> |- |ST 59104 73117 |Scheduled monument | |Medieval vaults N of St Peter's Church<ref>{{National Heritage List for England|num=1003065|desc=Medieval vaults N of St Peter's Church|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref> |- |ST 59122 73096 |II* |1959 (amended 1995) |[[St Peters Church, Castle Park, Bristol|Church of St Peter, Castle Park]]<ref>{{National Heritage List for England|num=1282177|desc=Church of St Peter, Castle Park|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref> |- |ST59220 73158 |II |1959 (amended 1995) |Castle keep remains<ref>{{National Heritage List for England|num=1202051|desc=Castle keep remains|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref> |- |ST59354 73230 |II |1959 |Castle wall remains<ref>{{National Heritage List for England|num=1204473|desc=Castle wall remains|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref> |- |ST 59373 73129 |Scheduled monument | |[[Bristol Castle]] vaulted chambers<ref>{{National Heritage List for England|num=1006987|desc=Bristol Castle vaulted chambers|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref> |- |ST 59372 73128 |II | |Vaulted chambers at Bristol Castle<ref>{{National Heritage List for England|num=1202476|desc=Vaulted chambers at Bristol Castle|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref> |- |}

'''Civil service examinations''' (also '''public tendering''') are examinations implemented in various countries for recruitment and admission to the [[civil service]]. The most ancient example of such exams were the [[imperial examination]]s of [[History of China#Ancient China|ancient China]].

{{advert|date=December 2016}} '''Deception technology''' is an emerging category of [[cyber security]] defense. Deception technology products can detect, analyze, and defend against [[zero-day attack|zero-day]] and advanced attacks, often in real time. They are automated, accurate,<ref>Lawrence Pingree quotes in article: {{cite web|url=https://www.csoonline.com/article/3113055/security/deception-technology-grows-and-evolves.html|title=Deception technology grows and evolves|work=CSO Online|author=Maria Korolov|date=August 29, 2016}}</ref> and provide insight into malicious activity within [[internal network]]s which may be unseen by other types of cyber defense. Deception technology enables a more proactive security posture by seeking to deceive the attackers, detect them and then defeat them, allowing the enterprise to return to normal operations.
Existing [[Defense in depth (computing)|defense-in-depth]] cyber technologies have struggled against the increasing wave of sophisticated and persistent human attackers. These technologies seek primarily to defend a perimeter, but both [[firewall (computing)|firewalls]] and [[Endpoint security|end-point security]] cannot defend a perimeter with 100% certainty. [[Cyber-attack]]ers can penetrate these networks and move unimpeded for months, stealing data and [[intellectual property]]. [[Heuristics]] may find an attacker within the network, but often generate so many alerts that critical alerts are missed. Since 2014 attacks have accelerated and there is evidence that cyber-attackers are penetrating traditional defenses at a rapidly increasing rate.
Deception technology considers the human attacker's point of view and methodology for exploiting and navigating networks to identify and [[Data theft|exfiltrate]] data. It integrates with existing technologies to provide new visibility into the internal networks, share high probability alerts and threat intelligence with the existing infrastructure.
==Technology: high level view==
Deception technology automates the creation of traps (decoys) and/or lures which are mixed among and within existing [[IT]] resources to provide a layer of protection to stop attackers that have penetrated the [[Computer network|network]]. Traps (decoys) are IT [[Asset (computer security)|assets]] that either use real licensed [[operating system]] software, or are emulations of these devices.
Traps (decoys) which use emulations can also imitate [[medical device]]s, [[automated teller machine]]s (ATMs),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://issuu.com/paymentweek/docs/pq2016_2020_final2|title=Payments Week Issue - go to page 42|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> retail point of sale systems, switches, routers and much more. Lures are generally real information technology resources (files of varying kinds) which are placed on actual IT assets.
Upon penetrating the network, attackers seek to establish a [[Backdoor (computing)|backdoor]] and then use this to identify and exfiltrate data and intellectual property. They begin moving laterally through the internal [[VLAN]]s and almost immediately will "look at" one of the traps (decoys). Interacting with one of these "decoys" will trigger an alert. These alerts are very high probability and almost always coincide to an ongoing attack. The deception is designed to lure the attacker in – the attacker may consider this a worthy asset and continue by injecting [[malware]]. Deception technology generally allows for automated static and dynamic analysis of this injected malware and provides these reports through automation to the security operations personnel. Deception technology may also identify, through indicators of compromise (IOC), suspect end-points that are part of the compromise cycle. Automation also allows for an automated memory analysis of the suspect end-point, and then automatically isolating the suspect end-point. Many partner integrations allow for a variety of implementation paths for existing enterprise and government customers.
==Specialized applications==
[[Internet of things|Internet of things (IoT)]] devices are not usually scanned by legacy defense in depth cyber defense and remain prime targets for attackers within the network. Deception technology can identify attackers moving laterally into the network from within these devices.
Integrated [[turnkey]] devices that utilize [[embedded operating system]]s, but do not allow these operating systems to be scanned or closely protected by embedded end-point or intrusion detection software are also well protected by a deception technology deployment in the same network. Examples include [[SCADA|process control systems (SCADA)]] used in many manufacturing applications on a global basis. Deception technology has been associated with the discovery of [[Zombie Zero]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtmarko/2014/07/10/trojan-hardware-spreads-apts/|title=How a Scanner Infected Corporate Systems and Stole Data: Beware Trojan Peripherals|first=Kurt|last=Marko|publisher=}}</ref> an [[attack vector]] wherein deception technology identified an attacker utilizing malware embedded in [[barcode reader]]s which were manufactured overseas.
[[Medical device]]s are particular vulnerable to cyber attacks within the healthcare networks. As [[FDA]]-certified devices they are closed systems and not accessible to standard cyber defense software. Deception technology can surround and protect these devices and identify attackers using these for backdoor placement and data exfiltration. Recent documented cyber attacks on medical devices include [[x-ray machine]]s, [[CT scan]]ners, [[MRI]] scanners, [[blood gas]] analyzers, [[Picture Archiving and Communication System|PACS]] systems and many more. Networks utilizing these devices can be protected by deception technology. This attack vector, called [[MEDJACK|medical device hijack or medjack]], is estimated to have penetrated many hospitals worldwide.{{failed verification|date=December 2016}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.surgicalproductsmag.com/article/2016/07/dangerous-state-medical-cybersecurity|title=The Dangerous State of Medical Cybersecurity|date=13 July 2016|publisher=}} </ref>
Specialized deception technology products are now capable of addressing the rise in [[ransomware]]. Select products<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthcareitnews.com/news/trapx-launches-ransomware-deception-tool-cryptotrap|title=TrapX launches ransomware deception tool, CryptoTrap|date=25 August 2016|publisher=}}</ref> can deceive ransomware into engaging in an attack on a decoy resource, while isolating the infection points and alerting the cyber defense software team.
==History==
[[Honeypot (computing)|Honeypots]] were perhaps the first very simple form of deception. A honeypot appeared simply as an unprotected information technology resource and presented itself in an attractive way to a prospective attacker already within the network. The notion of honeypots deceiving attackers, perhaps delaying and identifying them, and then ultimately supporting efforts to shut down the attack was a good one. Potential benefits aside, most early honeypots exhibit challenges with functionality, integrity and overall efficacy in meeting these goals. Key was the lack of automation that enabled broad scale of deployment. A deployment strategy would seek to cover the enterprise where up to tens of thousands of VLANS must be protected won't be economically efficient using manual processes and manual configuration.
The gap between legacy honeypots and modern deception technology has diminished over time and will continue to do so. Modern honeypots constitute the low end of the deception technology space today.
==Differentiation from competitive/cooperative technologies== {{see also|Alarm fatigue}} Traditional cyber defense technologies, such as firewalls and end-point security, generate many alerts. In a large enterprise the alert volume may reach, in some cases, millions of alerts per day. Security operations personnel cannot process most of the activity easily, yet it only takes one successful penetration to compromise an entire network.
Deception technology produces alerts that are the end product of a [[Binary number|binary]] process. Probability is essentially reduced to two values: 0% and 100%. Any party that seeks to identify, [[Ping (networking utility)|ping]], enter, view any trap (decoy) or utilizes a lure is immediately identified by this behavior. Anyone touching these traps or lures should not be doing so. This is an advantage over heuristics and probability-based approaches and the many thousands of extraneous alerts these techniques generate.
Best practice shows that deception technology is not a stand-alone strategy. Deception technology is an additional compatible layer to the existing defense-in-depth cyber defense. Partner integrations make it most useful and the goal is to add protection for the most advanced and sophisticated human attackers that will successfully penetrate the perimeter.
==Market size and adoption== The technical innovation of deception technology been received by the market. An [[industry analyst]] identified ten top technologies for information security in 2016, one of which were deception technology.
An industry analyst predicted in August 2016 that the deception technology market is currently (in 2016) approximately $50 to $100 million globally, and further predicted $100 million to $200 million in revenue by 2018. This same analyst earlier noted that, "by 2018 ... 10 percent of enterprises will use deception tools and tactics, and actively participate in deception operations against attackers". [[Gartner]] also noted deception technology as a "far underutilized technology that can provide serious advantages over attackers (cyber attackers)".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.gartner.com/lawrence-pingree/2016/09/28/deception-related-technology-its-not-just-a-nice-to-have-its-a-new-strategy-of-defense/|title=Deception related technology - its not just a "nice to have", it's a new strategy of defense - Lawrence Pingree|date=28 September 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
Two other important analysts have recently predicted a market size exceeding $1 billion by 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cio.com/article/3113444/security/deception-technology-grows-and-evolves.html|title=Deception technology grows and evolves|first=Maria|last=Korolov|publisher=}}</ref> Adoption is being fueled, in part, by continued, highly visible targeted attacks on large enterprise and government institutions globally.
Market Research Media estimates the cumulative deception technology market value at $12 billion (2017–2022), growing at about 19% CAGR.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.marketanalysis.com/?p=398|title=Deception Cybersecurity Market Forecast 2017-2022|date=9 February 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
==Participating vendors==
The list of participating vendors includes:
Allure Security Technology, Acalvio Technologies,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.acalvio.com/|title=Acalvio – Advanced Threat Defense|first=Acalvio|last=Technologies|website=www.acalvio.com}}</ref> Attivo Networks,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.attivonetworks.com/|title=Deception-Based Threat Detection - Attivo Networks|website=Attivo Networks}}</ref> CounterCraft,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.countercraft.eu/|title=CounterCraft - Deception Platform with real-time active response|website=www.countercraft.eu}}</ref> CyberTrap,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cybertrap.com/|title=Revolutionary Deception Technology - next evolution of Cyber Security - CyberTrap|website=CyberTrap}}</ref> Cymmetria, ForeScout, GuardiCore, Hexis Cyber Solutions, [[Illusive Networks]], [[LogRhythm]], Percipient Networks, [[Rapid7]], Shape Security, Smokescreen Technologies,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://smokescreen.io|title=Smokescreen|website=Smokescreen}}</ref> Specter, Tamarin Security, Thinkst, TrapX Security and Topspin Security.
==See also== * [[Cybercrime]] * [[Network security]] * [[Proactive cyber defense]]

==Further reading== * {{cite book|title=Honeypots tracking hackers|author=Lance Spitzner|publisher=[[Addison-Wesley]]|isbn=0-321-10895-7|year=2002}} * {{cite book|title=[[Reverse Deception: Organized Cyber Threat Counter-Exploitation]]|author=Sean Bodmer, CISSP, CEH, Dr Max Kilger, PhD, DrPH(c) Gregory Carpenter, CISM, Jade Jones, Esq., JD|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill Education]]|isbn=978-0071772495|year=2012}}
