{{for|the 2011 American film|10 Years (2011 film)}} {{Infobox film | name = Ten Years | image = File:Ten_Years_HK_poster.jpg | alt = | caption = | film name = 十年 | directors = {{plainlist| *Kwok Zune *Wong Fei-pang *Jevons Au *Chow Kwun-Wai *Ng Ka-leung }} | producer = {{plainlist| *Ng Ka-leung *Mandrew Kwan *Jevons Au *Frankie Chan *Andrew Choi }} | writer = | screenplay = | story = | based on = | starring = {{plainlist| *Peter Chan *Wong Ching *Lau Ho-Chi *Kin-Ping Leung *[[Liu Kai-chi]] *Siu Hin Ng }} | narrator = | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = Ten Years Studio
109G Studio
Four Parts Production | distributor = | released = {{film date|2015|12|17|Hong Kong|df=y}} | runtime = 104 minutes | country = Hong Kong | language = Cantonese | budget = [[Hong Kong dollar|HK$]]600,000 | gross = HK$6 million }} '''''Ten Years''''' ({{zh|c=十年|j=Sap6 Nin4}}) is a 2015 Hong Kong [[dystopia]]n [[speculative fiction]] [[anthology film]]. It offers a vision of the semi-autonomous territory in the year 2025, with human rights and freedoms gradually diminishing as the [[Government of China|mainland Chinese government]] exerts increasing influence there. Produced on a shoestring budget, the film was a surprise hit, beating ''[[Star Wars: The Force Awakens]]'' at the [[Yau Ma Tei]] cinema where it was first released. Due to the film's sensitive political themes, mainland Chinese authorities [[Censorship in China|censored]] reports mentioning ''Ten Years'' except in terms of condemnation. State television channels and major internet sites were prohibited from broadcasting the [[35th Hong Kong Film Awards]] live as the film was nominated for [[Hong Kong Film Award for Best Film|Best Film]], which it eventually won. ==Plot== The film comprises five short stories set in the year 2025. ===''Extras''=== Prior to an [[International Labour Day]] celebration, government officials concoct a [[false flag]] assassination plot to foment public support for legislation of the [[Hong Kong Basic Law Article 23|National Security Law]]. They hire two petty gangsters to execute the plot: Hairy (Zerisawa Courtney Wu), a middle-aged low-level [[Triad (organized crime)|triad]] member, and Peter (Peter Chan), an immigrant from India. While the two argue over who should fire the gun, the director of the [[Liaison Office of the Central People's Government in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region|Liaison Office]] decides that the leaders of both the TMD and the Fortune Parties are to get shot with real bullets, so as to instigate greater panic in the territory. Misbelieving they will get paid and flee to India afterwards, both Hairy and Peter attempt the assassination but are killed instantly on scene by the police. Later, the government identifies the perpetrators as terrorists and restates the significance of the upcoming legislation. Director Kwok Zune stated that the triad-like behaviour of the officials was inspired by real-world pro-establishment groups in Hong Kong, who were accused of beating and sexually assaulting pro-democratic protesters during the [[2014 Hong Kong protests]]. ===''Season of the End''=== Wong Ching (herself) and Lau Ho-chi (himself) attempt to preserve objects from homes destroyed by [[bulldozer]]s. The last specimen Lau wants to create is his own body. ===''Dialect''=== As the government enacts laws limiting operating areas of non-[[Standard Mandarin|Mandarin]]-speaking [[Hong Kong taxi|taxi]] drivers, a Cantonese-speaking driver (Leung Kin-ping) finds himself marginalised as he fails to pass the national Mandarin proficiency test. The driver's wife instructs him to stop using Cantonese with their son, Kongson, so that the boy will do better at his Mandarin [[medium of instruction]] school. A series of vignettes further illustrate the increasing dominance of Mandarin and Leung's struggle adjusting. He is unable to make himself understood by his Mandarin GPS unit and is ridiculed by a passenger for it. Two Mandarin-speaking fares opt to take another cab when they realise he cannot speak the language. One of his passengers, an office lady ([[Catherine Chau]]), is fired from her job for failing to clearly explain something to a client in Mandarin. The film alludes to a 2003 real-world proposal by the [[Transport Department]] that failed, as well as a regulation introduced in [[Wuhan]]. In [[Mainland China]], Mandarin (a.k.a. Putonghua) is promoted as a national language, and legislation such as the [[Guangdong National Language Regulations]] restricts the use of Cantonese and all other varieties of Chinese. The name ''Dialect'' comes from the fact that the Mainland government refers to Cantonese as a [[dialect]] despite the fact that it is [[mutually unintelligible]] with Mandarin. The short was directed by Jevons Au Man-kit, a graduate of the [[The Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts|Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts]], who said that the taxi driver's plight was influenced by his own struggles to write scripts in Mandarin in an increasingly Mainland-oriented Hong Kong film sector. ===''Self-immolator''=== [[File:HK British Consulate Justice Drive 1.JPG|thumb|The British Consulate-General, location of the eponymous self-immolation]] Au-yeung Kin-fung (Ng Siu-hin), a young hardline supporter for [[Hong Kong independence]], becomes the first to be convicted under the National Security Law and dies during a [[hunger strike]] in prison. An unknown person commits [[self-immolation]] in front of the [[British Consulate-General, Hong Kong|British Consulate-General]] in [[Admiralty, Hong Kong|Admiralty]]. This escalates public concerns about Hong Kong's undecided future beyond 2047. Au-yeung's friend Karen (Tanzela Qoser) is initially feared to be the self-immolator but is later revealed to have been kidnapped by secret police. Au-yeung's allies, led by Marco ([[Neo Yau Hawk-Sau|Neo Yau]]), break into and set fire to the [[Liaison Office of the Central People's Government in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region|Central Government Liaison Office]] in [[Sai Wan]], while a group of Christians gather and pray outside the British Consulate-General to urge the Britons to uphold the [[Sino-British Joint Declaration]] co-signed with the Beijing authorities. The Communist Party labels the demand for independence a diplomatic affair, thereby justifying the deployment of the [[People's Liberation Army]] in the city. The protests in Sai Wan and Admiralty are crushed violently. As a [[Flashback (narrative)|flashback]] reveals, after witnessing Au-yeung being severely beaten by police, an old woman was moved to commit self-immolation outside the British Consulate-General. The film ends on a prolonged shot of her umbrella burning, alluding to the [[Umbrella Movement]]. The storytelling is intertwined with interviews with commentators analysing ongoing events and providing background information such as Hong Kong's removal from the [[United Nations list of Non-Self-Governing Territories|UN decolonisation list]] in 1972 at China's behest. Directed by Chow Kwun-wai, ''Self-immolator'' alludes to the common practice of self-immolation in Mainland China as a form of protest, particularly [[List of political self-immolations|among Tibetans]]. Chow stated that while the plot of this piece may seem extreme, "In 2004, people would also find it hard to believe that [the police can drag a protester into a dark corner and beat him up]", alluding to the [[beating of Ken Tsang]] and other incidents of police brutality during the [[2014 Hong Kong protests]].{{cite news|last1=Yau|first1=Elaine|title=Ten Years: Hong Kong film that beat Star Wars at the box office, and the directors behind it|url=http://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/film-tv/article/1895992/ten-years-hong-kong-film-beat-star-wars-box-office-and-directors|work=South China Morning Post|date=29 December 2015}} ===''Local Egg''=== Sam ([[Liu Kai-chi]]), a grocery store keeper, is told about the closure of the last chicken farm in Hong Kong. He then visits his egg supplier, farm owner Cheung who recalls the government's actions to gradually kill off [[Agriculture and aquaculture in Hong Kong|the industry]] despite the fact that he has been meeting their demands. Sam's store is frequently checked by Youth Guards, members of a [[Red Guards (China)|Red Guards]]-like uniform group, since his use of "local eggs" on his label is on the censor list. He doubts why "local eggs" must be relabeled "Hong Kong eggs" when they refer to the same thing. Sam finds his son Ming among a squad of Youth Guards [[Egging|throwing eggs]] at a bookstore, but Ming assures his father that he has kept his teaching in mind and has not participated in the vandalism; instead, he often leaks the censor lists and actions to bookstore keepers so that they can remain safe and preserve the books. Relaxed at his son's critical thinking, Sam reminds a bookstore keeper not to get used to such suppressive acts. ===Epilogue=== ''Ten Years'' ends with a quote from the [[Book of Amos]]: {{cquote|It is an evil time. Seek good, and not evil, that you may live.|source={{Bibleverse|Amos|5:13b-14a|NIV}}}} and "Already too late" fading out and replaced by "Not too late". ==Production== The independent film was conceived by Ng Ka-leung, a graduate of the [[Hong Kong Polytechnic University]]. Ng said that the idea predated the [[Umbrella Movement]], and was inspired by ongoing political, educational and housing problems. He explained in late 2015: {{Quote|text=I had the idea for ''Ten Years'' early last year. I had been feeling dejected for years about the lack of future for Hong Kong. The [[Moral and national education|national education controversy]] showed that the next generation are at risk of ideological indoctrination. Political, education and housing problems have festered for years and all protest movements have turned out to be futile in the end. I wanted to make a film to flesh out possible future scenarios so people might be goaded into thinking more about the future path Hong Kong should take.}} The film was produced on a budget of HK$500,000 (US$64,000).{{cite news|title=Low-budget film on Hong Kong future turns into blockbuster|url=http://www.ejinsight.com/20160106-low-budget-film-on-hong-kong-future-turns-in-blockbuster/|work=Hong Kong Economic Journal|date=6 January 2016}} The cast and crew were mainly volunteers.{{cite news|last1=Griffiths|first1=James|title='Ten Years': Dark vision of Hong Kong's future proves surprise box office hit|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/01/20/asia/hong-kong-ten-years-future/|website=[[CNN]]|publisher=Cable News Network|date=21 January 2016}} It was filmed in Hong Kong. ==Release== [[File:Ten Years movie screen in City Art Square 201604.jpg|thumb|A community screening of ''Ten Years'' on 1 April 2016 in front of [[Sha Tin Town Hall]].]] The film was featured at the [[Hong Kong Asian Film Festival]] in November 2015 before its general release. It was initially released on only one screen in Hong Kong at the [[Broadway Cinematheque]] in Yau Ma Tei at the end of 2015. It was a surprise hit, and subsequently received a release at select UA Cinemas. It was further picked up by two independent cinemas, the [[Kowloonbay International Trade & Exhibition Centre|Metroplex]] in [[Kowloon Bay]] and the Ma On Shan Classics Cinema. The Metroplex decided to show the film in its largest cinema (430 seats) boosting ticket sales. By early February 2016 only the independent cinema in Ma On Shan was showing the film. It ended its run there following the weekend of 12 February.{{cite news|last1=Timmons|first1=Heather|title=Hong Kong’s popular, lucrative horror movie about Beijing has disappeared from theaters|url=http://qz.com/615831/the-most-successful-movie-made-in-hong-kong-in-years-has-been-pulled-from-theaters/|work=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]]|date=16 February 2016}} Since being pulled from theatres, the film has been showing at private screening at universities and other rented venues, advertised on social media. In February 2016 the international distribution rights for the film were purchased by [[Golden Scene]], a Hong Kong-based distributor.{{cite news|last1=Yuen|first1=Chantal|title=Int’l distribution rights for dystopian HK film Ten Years purchased by Golden Scene|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2016/02/17/international-rights-for-dystopian-hong-kong-film-ten-years-picked-up-by-golden-scene/|work=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]|date=17 February 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Frater|first1=Patrick|title=Berlin: Golden Scene Picks up Hong Kong Political Drama ’10 Years’|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/golden-scene-hong-kong-ten-years-1201705864/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=Variety Media, LLC|date=14 February 2016}} On 1 April 2016, with no cinemas screening the film despite high demand, ''Ten Years'' was simultaneously screened at 34 different public locations around Hong Kong, including the underside of motorway flyovers (in [[Sham Shui Po]] and [[Mei Foo]]), the public steps leading to the [[Sha Tin Town Hall]], and the forecourt of the [[Legislative Council Complex]]. The screenings were organised by a variety of community groups, educational institutions, and churches.{{cite news|last1=Grundy|first1=Tom|title=Where can you see 10 Years? A guide to screenings of Hong Kong’s most talked-about box office hit|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2016/03/28/where-you-can-see-10-years-a-guide-to-screenings-of-hong-kongs-most-talked-about-box-office-hit/|work=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]|date=28 March 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Cheung|first1=Karen|title=Dystopian Hong Kong film Ten Years to be shown at 30 locations on April 1|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2016/03/15/dystopian-hong-kong-film-ten-years-to-be-shown-at-30-locations-on-april-1/|work=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]|date=15 March 2016}} They were attended by thousands, many of whom were frustrated to have been unable to get tickets before the film was pulled from cinemas.{{cite news|last1=Zheping|first1=Huang|title=A movie about the dangers of Communist control brought Hong Kong residents out in droves|url=http://qz.com/652535/a-movie-about-the-dangers-of-communist-control-made-hong-kong-residents-come-out-in-droves/|work=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]]|date=1 April 2016}}{{cite news|title=Thousands of Hongkongers flock to see provocative box office hit Ten Years|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2016/04/02/thousands-of-hongkongers-flock-to-see-provocative-box-office-hit-ten-years/|work=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|date=2 April 2016}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== In the first month of its general release, most showings were sold out.{{cite news|last1=Wong|first1=Alan|title=Imagining Hong Kong’s Future, Under China’s Tightening Grasp|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/30/world/asia/hong-kong-ten-years.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=29 January 2016}} At the only cinema showing it in the week of its opening, it grossed more ticket sales than ''[[Star Wars: The Force Awakens]]'', and ranked top ten in Hong Kong's weekend box office.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?id=_fTENYEARS201&country=HK|title=Ten Years (2015)|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[IMDb]]}} At the end of January 2016 the film surpassed HK$5 million in box office earnings, which one of the directors called a miracle given the film's modest budget and limited screening.{{cite news|last1=Cheng|first1=Kris|title=‘A miracle’: Dystopian HK film ‘Ten Years’ passes HK$5 million mark at the box office|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2016/02/03/a-miracle-dystopian-hk-film-ten-years-passes-hk5-million-mark-at-the-box-office/|work=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]|date=3 February 2016}} At the time the film was only being shown at [[MegaBox (shopping mall)|UA Megabox]], the [[Kowloonbay International Trade & Exhibition Centre|Metroplex]] and the Ma On Shan Classics Cinema. By mid-February, when ''Ten Years'' ended its run at the sole screen where it was still being shown, the film had grossed more than HK$6 million.{{cite web|title=Ten Years (2015)|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?id=_fTENYEARS201&country=HK&wk=2016W2&id=_fTENYEARS201&p=.htm|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[IMDb|IMDb.com, Inc.]]|accessdate=10 March 2016}} The ''South China Morning Post'' reported that "''Ten Years''" topped the charts on Chinese download site zimuzu.tv after the Hong Kong Film Awards ceremony, but that users were disappointed to find they had downloaded the [[10 Years (2011 film)|2011 American film of the same name]].{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/film-tv/article/1934107/china-downloaders-seeking-hong-kong-set-ten-years-get-10-years|title=China downloaders seeking Hong Kong-set Ten Years get 10 Years, Hollywood rom-com, instead|date=7 April 2016|work=[[South China Morning Post]]}} ===Critical response=== ''Ten Years'' received generally positive reviews locally. Some viewers reportedly left the cinema in tears. ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out Hong Kong]]'' called the film "powerful, poignant, relevant and brave", as well as "nightmarish".{{cite news|title=The filmmakers behind 'Ten Years' on the resonating success of their dystopian vision|url=http://www.timeout.com.hk/film/features/75349/the-filmmakers-behind-ten-years-on-the-resonating-success-of-their-dystopian-vision.html|work=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out Hong Kong]]|date=14 January 2016}} The ''[[Hong Kong Economic Journal]]'' called it "well-constructed", and wrote: "Viewers will realize that although some of the scenes may seem unfamiliar and others way too radical, the stories are always anchored on developments in the past and the present. There’s always something in the movie that viewers can identify with, something believable and within the realm of the possible." Writing in the ''[[South China Morning Post]]'', Edmund Lee called the film "a reminder of the power of independent, intelligent filmmaking as a vehicle for social and political critique" and "one of the most thought-provoking local films in years".{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Edmund|title=Film review: Ten Years – Hongkongers’ worst post-Occupy fears depicted in 5 short films|url=http://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/film-tv/article/1892429/film-review-ten-years-hongkongers-worst-post-occupy-fears-depicted|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|date=17 December 2015}} Alice Wu said: "Provocation is an art form. Perhaps the true value of Ten Years lies in how uncomfortable it is to us all... As a portrayal of our worst fears, it is arguably the quintessential political horror film of our time. It perfectly plays (or should it be 'preys'?) on many Hongkongers’ primal fears..."{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/comment/insight-opinion/article/1934694/love-it-or-hate-it-ten-years-points-common-enemy-hong-kong|title=Love it or hate it, Ten Years points to the common enemy in Hong Kong politics – fear|date=10 April 2016|work=[[South China Morning Post]]}} A review in ''[[Hong Kong Free Press]]'' responded that "while ''Global Times'' and other reviewers have primarily directed their critiques at the likelihood of the film's events actually taking place, the film cannot be entirely interpreted as a prediction for the year 2025. ''Ten Years'' is not a forecast calculated via econometric modelling; it is simply a portrayal of the Hong Kong public's worst fears. Perhaps a more pertinent question raised by the film is why people have come to dread – rather than look forward to – the city’s future. The answer is probably because we have been shown no realistic alternative."{{cite news|last1=Tong|first1=Elson|title=Ten Years: A film that speaks to Hong Kong’s worst fears|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2016/02/07/ten-years-film-speaks-hong-kongs-worst-fears/|work=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]|date=7 February 2016}} The same reviewer observed a message about belonging in Hong Kong: "For example, ''Extras'' and ''Self-Immolator'' [...] portray mainland immigrants, South Asians and elderly characters without treating them as antagonists or resorting to stereotypes. The latter film even features a mixed-race relationship, advocating the idea that Hong Kong identity should be based on civic, not ethnic, factors." The film was selected to be screened at the 18th Taipei Film Festival opening on 30 June 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/culture/film-tv/article/1939567/politically-charged-hong-kong-films-including-ten-years-headline|title=Politically charged Hong Kong films, including Ten Years, headline prestigious Taipei festival|date=28 April 2016|work=[[South China Morning Post]]}} ===Industry voices=== [[Peter Lam]], chairman of Media Asia and of the Hong Kong Tourism Board, said: "The fact that the film got the prize is a tragedy for Hong Kong's movie industry [because] politics has kidnapped the profession and politicised film-awarding events." Lam added that, from a film investor's perspective: "The movie did not possess the qualities of best film, as you can see that it was not nominated for best actress or best actor awards, nor was it a blockbuster." Crucindo Hung, former chairman of the Federation of Motion Film Producers of Hong Kong, criticised the award as "an out-of-your-mind and outrageous decision."{{cite news|last1=Lo|first1=Kinling|title=Backlash after `emotional win' for Ten Years|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/section-news.php?id=167917|work=[[The Standard (Hong Kong)|The Standard]]|date=5 April 2016}} Lam further defended his remark from criticism, but earned further rebuke to his statement implying that a [[wonton noodles]] shop ought never to be able to be voted the best restaurant in Hong Kong.{{cite web|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2016/04/18/can-a-wonton-noodles-shop-be-best-restaurant-in-hk-tycoon-blasts-dystopian-film-ten-years-winning-top-award/|title=Tourism Board chief blasts decision to grant Ten Years 'best film' award|work=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]}} Some members of the Chamber of Films said that they would submit a proposal to the Hong Kong Film Awards Association to change the voting mechanism of the awards. Daniel Lam, Chamber of Films member and owner of Universe Films, whose film ''Little Big Master'' lost out to ''Ten Years'', said that current voting mechanism "can be easily manipulated to produce an irrational result".{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/hong-kong-film-awards-local-881291|title=Hong Kong Film Awards: Local Producers Want Voting System Changes After 'Ten Years' Win|author=Karen Chu|date=6 April 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media|Prometheus Global Media, LLC]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/1940253/hong-kong-film-awards-faces-calls-change-voting-system-after|title=Hong Kong Film Awards faces calls to change voting system after controversial Ten Years named best picture|date=30 April 2016|work=South China Morning Post}} ===Political response=== On the other hand, the [[Chinese Communist Party]]-controlled ''[[Global Times]]'' called the film absurd and ridiculous, and accused the filmmakers of trying to spread anxiety. It referred to the film's political message as a "virus of the mind" and claimed its box office earnings were minimal.{{cite news|last1=Cheng|first1=Kris|title=State newspaper says dystopian HK film ‘Ten Years’ is ridiculous and promotes desperation|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2016/01/22/state-newspaper-says-dystopian-hk-film-ten-years-is-ridiculous-and-promotes-desperation/|work=Hong Kong Free Press|date=22 January 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Fung|first1=Owen|title=‘Ten Years’ film is absurd and too pessimistic, says Global Times|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/1903800/ten-years-film-absurd-and-too-pessimistic-says-global-times|work=South China Morning Post|date=22 January 2016}} Due to the fact that the film was nominated for best picture in the 35th [[Hong Kong Film Awards]], the state-owned [[China Central Television]] announced that it would not live telecast the ceremony, as it had done every year since 1991.{{cite news|last1=Sala|first1=Ilaria Maria|title=Ten Years – the terrifying vision of Hong Kong that Beijing wants obscured|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/11/ten-years-the-terrifying-vision-of-hong-kong-that-beijing-wants-obscured|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=11 March 2016}} The online video website [[Tencent]] has said that it will also not cover the event.{{cite news|last1=Yuen|first1=Chantal|title=Dystopian HK film Ten Years leads to Chinese media boycott of Hong Kong Film Awards|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2016/02/22/ten-years-banned-in-china/|accessdate=22 February 2016|agency=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]|date=22 February 2016}} China's leading film review websites [[Douban]] and Mtime.com do not allow users to create a page for the film.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} [[Derek Yee]], chairman of Hong Kong Film Awards, who presented the award to the directors, said that it had been hard to find anyone else to present the award, due to fears of being blacklisted for mainland opportunities. Major mainland news websites, including [[Sina Corp|Sina]] and Tencent, covered the awards ceremony, held 3 April 2016, but neglected to mention the winner of best picture, considered one of Asia's top film awards.{{cite news|last1=Wu|first1=Venus|last2=Kwok|first2=Donny|title=Film depicting China's shadow over Hong Kong wins top Asian award|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/us-china-film-tenyears-idUKKCN0X00VQ|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=3 April 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Brzeski|first1=Patrick|last2=Chu|first2=Karen|title=Controversial Dystopian Movie 'Ten Years' Wins Best Picture at Hong Kong Film Awards|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/controversial-dystopian-movie-ten-years-880302|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media|Prometheus Global Media, LLC]]|date=3 April 2016}} In mainland Chinese cities where [[TVB]], the main Hong Kong television channel, is aired, users on social media reported that the programme was blacked out and replaced with a cooking programme.{{cite news|last1=Wong|first1=Alan|title=China News Blackout as ‘Ten Years’ Takes Hong Kong Best Film Award|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/05/world/asia/hong-kong-china-film-award-ten-years.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=4 April 2016}} During the week of 11 April 2016, Apple was ordered by the Chinese [[State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television]] to shut down its iTunes Movie and iBooks stores,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/22/technology/apple-no-longer-immune-to-chinas-scrutiny-of-us-tech-firms.html|title=Apple Services Shut Down in China in Startling About-Face|last=Mozur|first=Paul|date=2016-04-21|last2=Perlez|first2=Jane|work=[[The New York Times]]|issn=0362-4331|accessdate=22 April 2016}} which had been approved approximately six months earlier.{{Cite web|url=http://www.macrumors.com/2016/04/21/apple-china-state-itunes-movies-ibooks/|title=Report: iTunes Movies and iBooks Stores in China Ordered Closed by Chinese State Agency|last=Sumra|first=Husain|accessdate=22 April 2016}} This appears to be in response to the availability of ''Ten Years'' in the iTunes Movie store. News of the store closures broke shortly before the movie became available on iTunes in Hong Kong.{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/culture/film-tv/article/1937744/ten-years-lands-itunes-hong-kong-apple-says-service-shut-down-china|title=As Ten Years lands on iTunes in Hong Kong, Apple says service shut down in China|date=22 April 2016|work=[[South China Morning Post]]}} ===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center" ! colspan="5" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | Awards and nominations |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! Association ! Category ! Nominee(s) ! Result ! Ref. |- | 22nd [[Hong Kong Film Critics Society Award]] | Film of Merit | ''Ten Years'' | {{Won}} | {{cite web|url=http://www.filmcritics.org.hk/%E5%AD%B8%E6%9C%83%E5%A4%A7%E7%8D%8E/%E5%BE%97%E7%8D%8E%E5%90%8D%E5%96%AE/%E7%AC%AC%E4%BA%8C%E5%8D%81%E4%BA%8C%E5%B1%86%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E9%9B%BB%E5%BD%B1%E8%A9%95%E8%AB%96%E5%AD%B8%E6%9C%83%E5%A4%A7%E7%8D%8E|title=第二十二屆香港電影評論學會大獎|website=Hong Kong Film Critics Society|language=Chinese|date=18 January 2016}} |- | [[35th Hong Kong Film Awards]] | [[Hong Kong Film Award for Best Film|Best Film]] | ''Ten Years'' | {{Won}} | |} ==Franchise== In October 2017, a pan-Asian franchise based on the film was announced.[http://www.thestandard.com.hk/sections-news_print.php?id=188549 Bleak Hong Kong film to become pan-Asian], Agence France-Presse, 18 October 2017, in The Standard [[Cinema of Japan|Japanese]], [[Cinema of Taiwan|Taiwanese]] and [[Cinema of Thailand|Thai]] versions are planned, each offering a very specific take on those societies' "hidden dangers and hidden fears", according to [[Rina B. Tsou]], one of five Taiwanese directors on that project. For instance, the Japanese version would explore a country "plagued by pollution and aging" as well as a "society where morality and personal history are manipulated by technology." "Surveillance and government control" in a Thailand a decade hence will be envisaged by director [[Aditya Assarat]], while the Taiwanese project foretells an island where "immigrant workers are systematically exploited and the loss of culture and dropping birth rate" have caused its inhabitants to turn to "virtual reality escapes." Executive producers for the franchise include Andrew Choi, one of the original Hong Kong 'Ten Years' producers, and Japanese filmmaker [[Hirokazu Kore-eda]]. ==See also== *''[[Hong Kong Will Be Destroyed After 33 Years]]'' – a 2014 short film with similar themes ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|5269560}} *{{Hkmdb title|18466}} *{{Allmovie title|655455}} *{{Mojo title|_fTENYEARS201|intl=yes}} *{{Rotten Tomatoes|ten_years_2015}} {{Best Film HKFA}} [[Category:2010s independent films]] [[Category:2015 films]] [[Category:Anthology films]] [[Category:Cantonese-language films]] [[Category:Dystopian films]] [[Category:Films set in 2025]] [[Category:Hong Kong independent films]] [[Category:Hong Kong speculative fiction films]] [[Category:Political repression]] [[Category:Video censorship in China]]

{{Infobox organization | name = Transnational Institute | abbreviation = TNI | logo = Official TNI Logo.svg | established = [[1974]] | founding_location = [[Amsterdam]] | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] | website = https://www.tni.org | leader_name = Fiona Dove | leader_title = Director | coords = {{coord|52.3839918|4.8801102|display=title,inline}} }}
The '''Transnational Institute''' (TNI), is an international non-profit research and advocacy [[Think_tank|think tank]] that was founded in 1974, [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]]. It claims to be promoting a "... just, democratic and sustainable world."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tni.org/en/page/introduction|title=Introduction|date=10 April 2009|publisher=}}</ref>
== History ==
TNI was founded in 1974 in Amsterdam. Initially it operated as an international arm of the [[Institute for Policy Studies]]. Later it continued as a non-profit worldwide organisation.{{When|date=October 2018}}
In [[1976]] the director of the institute ([[Orlando Letelier]]) was [[Assassination of Orlando Letelier|Assassinated]] by the Chilean secret police as ordered by [[Augusto Pinochet]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/oct/08/pinochet-directly-ordered-washington-killing-diplomat-documents-orlando-letelier-declassified|title=Pinochet directly ordered killing on US soil of Chilean diplomat, papers reveal|first=Jonathan|last=Franklin|date=8 October 2015|website=the Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ips-dc.org/about/history/|title=Our History - Institute for Policy Studies|publisher=}}</ref>
The activist [[Susan George (political scientist)|Susan George]] is chairman of the supervisory board of the TNI.{{When|date=October 2018}}
The members of the institute are involved in the civil society and the associative life of their respective countries. Based in Amsterdam, the permanent team of TNI consisted of twenty five people in 2006.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}
==Work==
The TNI publishes research papers, books and organises seminars and debates. Its members include activists, researchers, writers, [[scholars]], journalists and documentary makers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://search.socialhistory.org/Record/ARCH02363|title=Collection Summary: Transnational Institute Archives|website=search.socialhistory.org}}</ref> The organisation has specific interest sections called "programs". These are the fields the organisation currently focuses on.
=== Drugs & Democracy ===
The program analyses world wide trends on [[Drug policy|drugs-policies]] and promotes a pragmatic approach to [[drugs]] based on damage-control. It has written on countries in [[latin america]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/us-has-been-quietly-helping-mexico-with-new-high-tech-ways-to-fight-opium/2018/04/15/dc18eda0-26d5-11e8-a227-fd2b009466bc_story.html|title=U.S. has been quietly helping Mexico with new, high-tech ways to fight opium|first=|last=https://www.facebook.com/josh.partlow1|website=Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/reform-more-radical-than-war-on-drugs-1.1899567|title=Reform more radical than ‘war on drugs’|publisher=}}</ref> and [[southeast asia]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thediplomat.com/2017/10/a-new-drug-win-for-malaysia/|title=A New Drug Win for Malaysia?|first=David Hutt, The|last=Diplomat|publisher=}}</ref>
Ricardo Soberón, the Lawyer who was the drug tsar for Peru until 2012, has carried out research for TNI.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-16500137|title=Peru replaces drug tsar Soberon|date=10 October 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.druglawreform.info/en/about-us/researchers/item/305-ricardo-soberon-es|title=Researchers - Ricardo Soberón|first=|last=Amira|website=www.druglawreform.info}}</ref>
=== Public Alternatives ===
The public alternatives program publishes research and organises events on the following topics
* The effects of [[privatisation]] such as water privatisation<ref>{{cite web|url=https://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/in-pipeline-a-plan-to-privatise-water-supply-in-cities/|title=In pipeline, a plan to privatise water supply in cities|date=22 September 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/jan/30/water-privatisation-worldwide-failure-lagos-world-bank|title=Water privatisation: a worldwide failure? - John Vidal|first=John|last=Vidal|date=30 January 2015|website=the Guardian}}</ref> * [[Energy democracy]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.energy-democracy.net/?p=191|title=Energy democracy - ENERGY DEMOCRACY|date=4 December 2016|publisher=}}</ref> * The return of [[public services]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.citymetric.com/politics/more-830-cities-have-brought-essential-services-back-under-public-control-others-should|title=More than 830 cities have brought essential services back under public control. Others should follow - CityMetric|website=www.citymetric.com}}</ref> or [[remunicipalization]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.epsu.org/article/remunicipalisation-becomes-unstoppable-trend|title=Remunicipalisation becomes an unstoppable trend - EPSU|website=www.epsu.org}}</ref> * Transformative Cities<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.p2pfoundation.net/the-power-of-a-transformative-city/2018/05/23|title=The power of a transformative city - P2P Foundation|date=23 May 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/sol-trumbo-vila-nick-buxton/transformative-cities-initiative-unique-participatory-award|title=Transformative Cities Initiative: a unique participatory award|date=29 May 2018|website=openDemocracy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://dezwijger.nl/programma/transformative-cities|title=Transnational Institute:Transformative Cities|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Participatory democracy]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/wfd/ahdaf-soueif-nick-buxton/our-common-ground-salute-to-young-global-collective|title=Our common ground: a salute to the Young Global Collective|date=23 January 2017|website=openDemocracy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/deniz-kellecioglu/battle-for-minds-and-role-of-human-behaviour-in-generating-plutocracies|title=The battle for minds, and role of human behaviour in generating plutocracies|date=26 January 2017|website=openDemocracy}}</ref>
===Trade & Investment===
'''Publications''' * ''Financialisation: A Primer'' (2018 update) - about [[financialization]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tni.org/en/publication/financialisation-a-primer|title=Financialisation: A Primer|date=13 September 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
===Other programs=== * Myanmar * War & Pacification * Colombia * Agrarian & Environmental Justice * Corporate Power
